title: Legacy systems: how to deal with them
author: Daniel Pinho
content:
Discover when to modernise or replace your legacy system, and how to make the right move for lasting business impact.

Every company has (at least) one – a legacy system that’s too old to love, too critical to replace.

It runs your core operations, stores years of valuable data, and somehow still holds the business together. Yet every new integration feels like a small act of engineering heroism, every upgrade a gamble between “it might work” and “we might break everything.”

Legacy systems are how your company has operated for years, and that’s exactly why changing them is so complicated. Even the thought of replacing them seems daunting. However, it may be key to reduce costs and risks, while speeding daily operations.

The real question isn’t how old your system is. It’s whether it’s still helping your business move forward. So before committing to a complete overhaul, take a step back. You might not need a brand-new system. Just the right approach to make your existing one smarter, faster, and ready for what’s next. And that’s exactly what this guide explores.

What is a legacy system?

A legacy system is essentially an older software or IT setup that a business keeps running because it still “does the job”, even if it’s creaky, hard to update, and sometimes feels like it’s stuck in the past. These systems often hold critical data, support essential operations, and are deeply woven into how a company functions. While they may be reliable, they can slow down innovation, complicate integrations, and make scaling a headache.

There’s no age threshold to call any piece of software a legacy system. They show up in all sorts of forms across businesses, like old software or even entire IT infrastructures that have been around for decades. Some common examples include:

ERP platforms

. They handle core processes like finance, HR, and

supply chain

, but often require custom workarounds just to keep them talking to newer tools.

Custom-built CRM software

. Designed years ago for very specific workflows, they can struggle to scale as

customer needs

evolve or as new channels appear.

Outdated reporting tools

. Many companies still rely on old

dashboards

or Excel-heavy systems that demand manual updates, making real-time insights almost impossible.

Old communication platforms

. Legacy email, intranet, or messaging systems that lack modern collaboration features, slowing down teams who are used to sleek, intuitive tools.

Why you probably still rely on legacy systems

Even though legacy systems can be clunky, costly to maintain, and a headache for modernisation, you probably choose to keep them alive for a number of very practical reasons:

They’re critical to operations

. Many legacy systems run the backbone of a company, from finance to customer data. Even small changes may require extensive testing.

High replacement cost

. Upgrading or replacing a legacy system can feel like buying a small spaceship: expensive, complex, and time-consuming.

Data entanglement

. Years of business data live inside these systems.

Migrating it safely

is a careful, delicate process.

Familiarity

. Teams have learned the quirks, workarounds, and patterns of these systems over years. Change can be scary and slow to adopt.

Regulatory or compliance constraints

. In sectors like banking or healthcare, legacy systems often meet strict requirements that new tools haven’t been certified for yet.

Problems caused by a legacy system (and how to fix them)

Legacy systems can feel like both a safety net and a trap. They keep operations running, but they also create a set of predictable, yet painful, challenges.

1. Slow innovation

Legacy systems often can’t keep up with new technologies, integrations, or customer expectations. Adding new features can take months instead of days. In fact,

70% of top executives

say legacy systems limit their ability to innovate.

How to fix

: Introduce modular tools or APIs that wrap around the legacy system. This lets you modernise workflows without ripping everything out at once.

2. High maintenance costs

Organisations frequently discover that vast chunks of their IT budget disappear just to keep the lights on: some studies show up to

70% or more

of spending goes into maintaining legacy systems, leaving little fuel for real change.

How to fix:

Conduct a system audit to identify which parts are truly critical. Consider phased replacement or cloud migration for the components that drain resources.

3. Data bottlenecks and silos

Important data is locked in old formats, making reporting, analytics, and decision-making slow or inaccurate.

How to fix:

Implement a

data integration

layer or ETL (extract, transform, load) processes. Slowly consolidate key data into a modern, accessible platform.

4. Security vulnerabilities

Older systems are often unsupported, missing patches, and more exposed to breaches.

How to fix:

Strengthen perimeter security, apply virtual patches where possible, and plan for a

gradual migration

to systems that are actively maintained.

5. Employee frustration and inefficiency

Teams adapt with workarounds, which leads to errors, delays, and burnout.

How to fix:

Provide modern interfaces or dashboards on top of the legacy system, and invest in targeted training so employees can work smarter.

When you don’t need to replace a legacy system

Legacy systems get a bad rap. Everyone tells you to replace them, yet in many cases, throwing the baby out with the bathwater is neither necessary nor smart. Here’s when

keeping (and modernising) your legacy system

is actually the right move:

1. It still does the job (reliability matters)

Old doesn’t always mean broken. If your legacy system consistently supports critical operations without frequent downtime, it’s providing real value. Instead of replacing it, focus on optimising processes around it. Small tweaks, better reporting layers, or workflow improvements can significantly extend its usefulness. Sometimes stability is more valuable than shiny new features.

2. Modern integration is possible

Many legacy systems weren’t built with modern integrations in mind, but clever workarounds exist. You can wrap APIs, add dashboards, or

automate data flows

around your old system. This lets you leverage new tech (analytics, cloud storage, mobile access) without dismantling the infrastructure that still works. You get modern capabilities without the cost and risk of a full replacement.

3. It holds critical data

Legacy systems often hold years of business-critical data. Extracting, cleaning, and migrating this information can be risky, time-consuming, and costly. Incremental modernisation allows you to maintain the

integrity of your data

while gradually improving accessibility, reporting, and decision-making capabilities.

5. It complies with regulations

In industries like finance, healthcare, or government, legacy systems often meet stringent regulatory standards. Swapping them out can introduce compliance risks. Modernisation, on the other hand, allows you to add functionality, reporting, or security upgrades while maintaining compliance, keeping operations smooth and worry-free.

Legacy system modernization or replacement?

There’s no universal answer. The right path depends on your business goals, how critical the system is, and how much risk (and disruption) you can afford. What you need isn’t a gut decision. It’s a strategy.

It starts with understanding how critical the system is to your operations and whether it’s truly holding you back. Sometimes, modernisation delivers quick wins (lower costs, minimal disruption, and faster results), especially when the system is stable but outdated. Replacement, on the other hand, makes sense when performance issues, security risks, or scalability limits are too severe to patch over.

The smartest move is often a hybrid one: modernise what brings immediate value, and plan replacement where it aligns with long-term goals. Consider costs beyond the technology itself, like training, adoption, and downtime matter just as much. By combining a phased approach with a clear strategic vision, you can evolve your systems at the right pace, keeping business continuity while building the foundation for future growth.

How to update legacy systems

1. Initiate with a focused assessment

Inventory the system: functions it supports, data it holds, external integrations, compliance constraints, and current costs (maintenance + incidents). Score each component on business criticality, change risk, and technical debt.

2. Define business outcomes and success metrics

Translate technical work into business KPIs: uptime improvement, lead time to deploy, reporting latency, cost reduction, user satisfaction, regulatory reporting accuracy. These metrics will drive prioritisation.

3. Design a layered migration strategy

Choose an approach per component: wrap (API façade), refactor (incremental code improvements), replatform (move to cloud), or replace. For each, define scope, dependencies, rollback plan and estimated effort.

4. Secure quick wins

Implement low-risk changes that deliver immediate value: add an API gateway, create a reporting data extract, build a user dashboard, or automate a manual process. Quick wins free budget and build trust.

5. Prototype and validate

Build a small, production-adjacent and validate with real users and real data slices. Measure against the KPIs set in step 2. Use feature flags and canary releases to limit exposure.

6. Plan data migration carefully

Map schemas, define transformation rules, validate data quality, and run dry-runs. Use incremental sync (CDC/ETL) where possible so both systems can run in parallel. Always have a verified rollback snapshot.

7. Implement integration and observability

Add monitoring, logging, and tracing before cutover. Implement health checks and automated alerts. Observability reduces blast radius during deployment.

8. Run staged rollout and parallel running

Start with a pilot business unit or region, run systems in parallel, compare outputs, and iterate. Only widen the rollout once reliability and data parity are proven.

9. Cutover, switch traffic, and stabilise

Use phased traffic shifts (e.g., 1% – 10% – 50% – 00%) and keep the legacy system available as a fallback for a defined period. Maintain a battle-plan: rollback steps, communication scripts, and a small on-call war room.

10. Post-launch review and continuous improvement

Measure against KPIs, collect user feedback, fix gaps, and document lessons learned. Close or archive legacy components following a final decommission checklist (data retention, compliance, backups).

Modernising a legacy system is a strategic decision that can redefine how your business operates. The real challenge is knowing when to modernise, when to replace, and how to do it without disrupting what already works. That’s where expertise makes the difference.

If you’re weighing your options, we’ll help you see the bigger picture, make confident choices, and turn legacy technology into a platform for future growth.

title: AI assistants: what works, what doesn’t, and how to choose the one that fits
author: Sérgio
content:
Learn how to choose an AI assistant that actually delivers value, with examples, pitfalls, and insights from real-world implementations.

Only about

5% of workers

feel they’re getting meaningful results from AI. That means the overwhelming majority are either underutilizing these tools, misusing them, or (worse), treating them as glorified toys that generate a little buzz but no real impact.

Some may think it’s a technology problem, but it’s more a human and strategic one. Installing an AI assistant isn’t enough. Without careful integration, proper training, and clear objectives, even the most sophisticated AI becomes little more than a fancy desk ornament: flashy, talked about at meetings, but fundamentally useless.

In this article, we’ll unpack what it really takes to make an AI assistant deliver value.

What are AI assistants?

AI assistants are digital tools that help you get work done faster and more accurately. They read information, process tasks, summarise content, draft messages, analyse data, keep track of what matters, and support decisions with context-aware suggestions. Tools like

ChatGPT, Microsoft Copilot or Google Gemini

adapt to your workflows, follow the rules you define, and integrate seamlessly into the way you already work.

If you receive a long client report, an AI assistant can instantly summarise the key insights, pull out action points, draft an email response, update your project tracker in tools like Notion or Slack, and remind you of upcoming deadlines — all without you switching between applications.

What is the difference between AI assistants and AI agents?

Simply put, AI assistants help you complete tasks, while

AI agents

help you run them.

Assistants wait for your input, like a prompt, a question, a file, an instruction. They support your workflow, but you’re still in the driver’s seat.

AI agents operate with more autonomy. You give them a goal, they break it down, decide what to do next, execute steps on their own, check the results, adjust, and keep going until the job is done.

Why AI assistants make work more productive

When implemented thoughtfully, AI assistants are like adding a team member who never sleeps, never complains, and actually enjoys doing the wearying stuff no one else wants.

1. They save (a lot of) time

AI assistants handle the low-value, repetitive chores, like scheduling meetings, chasing updates, sending reminders or summarising reports. People spend less time on “busy work” and more time on creativity, decision-making, and problem-solving. In other words: productivity levels go up, stress levels go down.

2. They save money

AI assistants work 24/7, handle multiple requests at once, and don’t need coffee breaks. That’s a round-the-clock operation for a fraction of the cost of hiring extra staff. They reduce operational expenses while keeping customers and internal teams happy.

3. They can get personal

AI assistants can analyse behaviours, preferences, and past interactions to deliver advice, recommendations, or responses that feel tailor-made. Whether suggesting the right product, sending relevant updates, or providing context-aware support, the assistant makes interactions feel smarter and more human, without anyone having to micromanage it.

Limitations of AI assistants

As you probably already know by using AI tools, they can make mistakes… they may misread a request, hallucinate a confident nonsense answer, or treat a niche scenario like it’s a global rule.

AI assistants only look smart because they’ve been fed oceans of data. But if those oceans are polluted (biased, outdated, overly niche, or missing entire user groups), the outcomes will reflect that. Skewed training data can create blind spots, unfair recommendations, and results that simply miss the mark.

If you want a high-performing assistant, you need to invest in the plumbing: data pipelines, validation rules, ownership, and ongoing maintenance. Otherwise, expect mediocre insights wrapped in confident sentences.

But even with clean data, reliable AI assistants are a challenge. After all, natural language is full of nuance, ambiguity and cultural context. And humans are experts at being vague. (“Can you sort this out?”, “Make it better”, “Handle the thing we discussed”.)

If your workflows require complex reasoning or domain-specific reading comprehension, evaluate assistants aggressively. The limitations appear fast.

And then there’s data security. AI assistants often access sensitive information, such as financials, customer data, internal documents, strategic decisions. If the assistant isn’t backed by proper encryption, access controls, audit logs, and regular updates, you’re handing your organisation’s crown jewels to a system that may or may not be lock-tight.

How to choose the right AI assistant

Here’s how to pick an assistant that actually earns its keep.

1. Start from outcomes

Be specific about the result you expect. Features are worthless without context. So, translate vague wishes into measurable outcomes:

2. Define the AI assistant’s guardrails

You should be able to set clear guardrails to the AI assistant, like block certain actions or require approvals. For example, you may want to define on which apps the assistant can work on. It should also respect your governance rules (like access control).

3. Evaluate transparency and control

You need explanations and control knobs. Can the assistant show why it suggested what it did? Can you correct it and have it learned?

4. Test with messy, real scenarios

If it only shines with “clean” demo data, it won’t survive your day-to-day. Test the assistant with a real ticket that took a long time to resolve or your actual monthly report dataset (with messy fields).

5. Set KPIs for you AI assistant

Just like you would do for any other team member, AI assisntants need KPIs, too. Track

time saved, adoption rate and accuracy.

6. Involve your (human) team

Your teams need to

like

using it. If the assistant feels slow, inflexible, or overly formal, adoption drops. Appoint an enthusiastic, credible sponsor from the business. Train real users on how to use the assistant and what to do when it fails.

AI assistants worth knowing (and what they do well)

Before choosing an AI assistant, it helps to look at what’s already out there. Below are a few examples that show how different approaches to AI can build momentum.

1. Microsoft Copilot

A productivity assistant woven into the Microsoft ecosystem. Ideal for organisations whose workdays revolve around Office 365 or Teams. And it works where people already work, meaning almost no onboarding pain.

What it does well

Organizes meetings with structured summaries and action points.

Helps draft emails and documents without sounding like an instruction manual.

Surfaces insights buried across Outlook, Teams, and SharePoint.

Reduces the time you waste searching for “that file someone shared last Tuesday”.

2. Perplexity AI

Best for people who spend their day researching, comparing options, and trying to get reliable answers fast—without juggling twenty tabs or manually checking every source.

What it does well

Pulls together clear, concise answers with high-quality citations so you always know where the information comes from.

Breaks down complex topics into digestible summaries, even when you’re not sure how to frame the question.

Surfaces real-time, web-based insights without you having to hunt for them.

Fits naturally into research-heavy workflows, making it easy to compile findings, create reports, and keep everything organised.

3. Notion AI

A favourite among fast-moving teams who want structure without bureaucracy. It works inside Notion, turning knowledge bases, project pages, and meeting notes into living, searchable systems.

What it does well

Creates summaries and action lists from messy notes.

Converts half-baked ideas into organised project pages.

Helps maintain team knowledge without needing a “documentation champion”.

Extends Notion’s modular system with genuinely useful automation.

4. Salesforce Einstein Copilot

The

AI layer that sits inside Salesforce

and makes all that CRM data work for you. Best for sales, service, and marketing teams who spend half their lives clicking through tabs.

What it does well

Suggests next-best actions based on real pipeline data.

Drafts messages, follow-ups, and case responses directly inside the CRM.

Surfaces insights about accounts, deals, sentiment, and conversion risk.

Automates CRM updates (so reps actually keep the CRM up to date).

5. OutSystems AI Copilot

For organisations building apps at speed,

OutSystems’ AI features

help teams design, develop, and deploy faster, without forcing developers to hunt for documentation.

What it does well

Generates application logic, screens, and workflows from natural language prompts.

Spots performance issues or bad architecture early, before they become expensive.

Speeds up low-code development without compromising quality.

Assists both technical and non-technical users in building functional prototypes quickly.

Most organisations are struggling because they’ve never had an assistant built around their reality. The gap between “we’re experimenting with AI” and “AI is driving measurable impact” is almost always the same: thoughtful design, solid integration, and a partner who knows how to turn good intentions into working systems.

title: Low-code automation: what it is, why it matters,and how to make it work
author: Bárbara Basílio
content:
Low-code automation helps organisations simplify complex workflows. But is the process as simple as it seems? Here’s how they’re making it work.

Slow approvals, redundant data entry, juggling multiple systems to complete simple tasks — if you were to list the most frustrating admin headaches, these would likely top it. And it’s no surprise. Early automation solutions promised sweeping productivity gains across everything from client proposals to expense management — yet conveniently glossed over long implementation times, steep learning curves, and inflexible systems.

Still, automation remains a vital need for businesses of all sizes. Which leads to a key question:

what’s the most efficient way to automate repetitive processes today?

Enter

low-code automation

— an approach that lets teams build automations through drag-and-drop interfaces and by connecting the tools they already use. But is it a truly practical alternative? And how does it complement the growing wave of

AI-powered automation

?

What is low-code automation?

Low-code automation uses visual interfaces, pre-built components, and just enough coding to allow both IT and business teams to build applications and automate processes faster and more efficiently.

In practice, it’s about connecting actions that used to be manual and time-consuming. For example:

When a customer places an order, the system automatically updates inventory, triggers an invoice, and sends a personalised confirmation — no manual entry needed.

When a new support ticket arrives, it’s automatically classified, assigned to the right team member, and added to a dashboard for real-time tracking.

When an email with a specific request is received, the content is extracted, logged into a database, and linked to an open project task — all without human intervention.

Low-code

automation removes unnecessary friction and makes space for speed, agility, and collaboration. It’s a response to a long-standing problem: innovation bottlenecked by technical debt and overloaded IT departments.

Why low-code automation matters

Simply put, because speed, resilience and adaptability became basic corporate skills.

Less IT intensive

In most organisations, IT teams are overworked. That means new solutions often take months. Low-code automation allows non-technical teams to design and launch simple workflows themselves, using intuitive visual tools instead of complex programming. For straightforward tasks, this empowers business users to act quickly without waiting for IT queues to clear. But when it comes to building more complex, integrated, or large-scale solutions — the kind that truly transform how an organisation operates — having expert support makes all the difference.

Eliminate manual work and repetitive tasks

No one enjoys spending hours copying data from one system to another or chasing for approvals. These tasks eat up time, create bottlenecks, and increase the chance of error. Low-code automation takes those repeatable steps — like sending notifications, logging entries, or routing requests — and runs them in the background. Consistently, and instantly.

Reduce errors and operational risk

Mistakes don’t just slow things down — they cost money and damage trust. Especially when they’re caused by manual data entry or inconsistent processes. Automation brings structure and consistency, ensuring the right steps happen in the right order, every time.

How to get started: a step-by-step guide for business leaders

You don’t need to be technical to make low-code automation work. What you need is clarity, alignment and the right use cases. Here’s how to begin.

1. Pick one process to start with

Pick a high-impact process that happens frequently and involves clear, defined steps.

Focus on tasks like expense approvals, client intake, or task assignment.

Ensure the process involves no more than 5 people to avoid complexity.

Start small to avoid getting overwhelmed.

2. Map it out with the people who do it

Understand the process from end-to-end with those who do it daily.

List steps and pain points with the people that actually use the process every day.

Create a simple process map, highlighting triggers, actions, and approvals.

Identify bottlenecks or repetitive tasks that are ideal for automation.

3. Choose a low-code platform that fits your needs

Select a low-code platform that integrates with your current tools and scales with your needs.

Look for platforms like OutSystems or Salesforce for enterprise-grade capabilities.

Ensure it has visual development functionality and pre-built templates to accelerate development.

Test the platform before committing to ensure it fits your specific requirements.

4. Build and test your first workflow

Start automating the repetitive parts first to see quick results.

Use your process map to create workflows that trigger notifications, move data, or generate documents.

Test with real users and iterate based on feedback.

Focus on automating the tasks that take the most time or cause the most errors.

5. Share results and expand

Communicate the impact of your automation to build momentum and gain support.

Measure time saved, errors reduced, and the process efficiency gained.

Share these results within the company to encourage further automation efforts.

Identify the next process to automate based on the feedback and results.

6. Hire a partner for deeper customisation

Even low-code platforms require a learning curve. We can help customise workflows and integrate with existing system, and assist in ensuring security, scalability, and governance. We also guide you through more complex automation, so you can focus on growth.

Low-code automation & AI

AI can be easily integrated into workflows with low-code. For example, you could add a step to generate a client proposal with ChatGPT everytime you add a lead to your CRM. That proposal could then be sent for human editing and approval, before being sent to the customer.

Unscoured, unique processes may require AI to be automated. In general, low-code automation excels at repetitive tasks, while AI automation handles unstructured data and steps remarkably well – even if humans are required in the loop. So choosing AI or low-code depends on the process you’re trying to automate.

And the best part? to the drag-and-drop features and pre-built AI models, teams can implement AI-powered automation without relying on complex coding or IT departments.

Low-code automation vs. RPA vs automation: what’s the difference

It’s easy to get caught up in the different buzzwords, but low-code automation, RPA (Robotic Process Automation), and traditional automation each serve different purposes.

Low-code automation

is all about building and adapting workflows quickly, using visual tools and minimal coding, perfect for teams that want flexibility without needing deep technical skills.

RPA

, on the other hand, focuses on automating repetitive, rule-based tasks using bots — great for handling structured, high-volume processes like data entry or invoice processing.

Traditional

automation

is typically more rigid, relying on coding to set up processes and often needing more time and resources to build.

Low-code automation pitfalls

While low-code automation is a powerful tool, it’s not without its challenges. Low-code platforms are fantastic for simple, step-by-step processes, but when it comes to highly customised workflows or complex integrations, you might hit a wall. That’s where the expertise of a partner, like Near Partner, can make all the difference, ensuring everything runs smoothly and is tailored to your needs.

Another risk is the temptation to automate too quickly without understanding the full scope of the process. Rushing can lead to errors, missed steps, or poorly designed workflows that create more issues than they solve.

Lastly, as with any new technology, a lack of proper governance and oversight can create chaos, especially when different teams start automating without standardised processes in place. It’s essential to approach low-code automation with a clear strategy and the right expertise to avoid these pitfalls.

Near Partner, your low-code automation partner

Near Partner

, we’ve fully embraced low-code development, and we understand that change can feel daunting — especially in traditionally conservative industries. There are questions: Is it secure? Is it easy to use? How do you ensure a smooth transition? These were the same concerns voiced by the clients who are now reaping the rewards of working with us. But here’s the truth: in today’s rapidly changing world, staying static is no longer an option. Those who have embraced change are already ahead of the competition.

Let’s start a conversation.

Reach out to Near Partner

and, together, we’ll explore how we can help you accelerate your journey into the digital future — whether you’re just starting, scaling up, or adapting to new challenges. While you’re at it, take a look at some of our

success stories

title: Agentic AI: what it is, why it matters, and how to make it work
author: Bárbara Basílio
content:
Agentic AI goes beyond assistants, acting autonomously to achieve business goals. Learn what it is, where it works, and how to use it effectively.

Despite the rapid adoption of AI across organisations, many teams still struggle to see real, sustained impact. Tools are deployed, pilots are launched, and dashboards light up, yet everyday work often looks much the same.

The issue is rarely the technology itself. More often, it’s about

how

AI is designed and embedded into operations. This is where agentic AI comes in. Instead of simply responding to prompts or supporting isolated tasks, agentic AI systems are designed to pursue goals, make decisions, and act autonomously within defined boundaries.

In this article, we’ll explore what agentic AI really is, how it differs from

AI assistants

, where it delivers value, and what it takes to implement it responsibly.

What is agentic AI?

Agentic AI refers to AI systems that operate as

autonomous agents

rather than reactive tools. Instead of waiting for a user command, an agentic AI is given a

goal

(for example, improving customer response times or keeping a sales pipeline healthy) and then decides how to achieve it.

To do that, an agentic system typically starts by understanding the objective it is responsible for. Then it breaks that objective into smaller tasks, decides what action to take next and executes those actions across systems or tools. Finally, it evaluates the results and adjusts its approach.

In simple terms, agentic AI doesn’t just help you do the work. It helps

run

the work.

Agentic AI vs AI assistants: what’s the difference?

AI assistants

support users. They respond to prompts, summarise information, draft content, analyse data, or suggest next steps, but they rely on human input to move forward – it’s what happens when you enter a prompt into ChatGPT.

Agentic AI systems

, on the other hand, operate with a degree of autonomy. Once a goal and guardrails are defined, they decide what to do next, act, check outcomes, and continue until the objective is met or human intervention is required. They orchestrate AI assistants to get the job done.

A simple way to think about it: AI assistants are

reactive;

agentic AI is

goal-driven.

Both have their place. The key is knowing when autonomy adds value and when it introduces unnecessary risk.

Why agentic AI can transform your workflow

When designed well, agentic AI can have a significant impact on how your organisation operates.

1. Reduced operational friction

Agentic systems can manage multi-step processes end to end: monitoring inputs, triggering actions, coordinating systems, and following up automatically. This reduces handoffs, delays, and manual oversight.

2. Increased autonomy

Instead of relying on people to constantly monitor dashboards or queues, agentic AI can watch for signals, detect anomalies, and act immediately. Decisions happen faster and consistently, even as volume grows.

3. It keeps humans focused on high-value work

By taking ownership of repetitive coordination and execution, agentic AI frees teams to focus on judgement, creativity, and complex problem-solving, areas where humans still outperform machines.

Where agentic AI works best

Agentic AI is most effective in environments where goals are clear, rules can be defined, and actions can be executed digitally.

Common examples include:

Customer operations

: routing cases, prioritising responses, triggering follow-ups, and escalating when needed;

Sales and revenue operations

: monitoring pipelines, updating

CRMs

, prompting next-best actions, and flagging risk;

IT and internal operations

: handling service requests, monitoring systems, and coordinating remediation steps;

Process automation

: managing workflows that span multiple tools, teams, or data sources.

The limitations and risks of agentic AI

Agentic AI brings autonomy into everyday operations, which inevitably changes how organisations think about risk. While the potential upside is significant, these systems need to be designed and governed carefully to avoid unintended consequences.

Loss of control without clear guardrails

Agentic systems act independently once goals are set. If boundaries are poorly defined, an agent may take actions that go beyond what teams are comfortable with, especially when interacting with sensitive systems or triggering irreversible processes. Clear permissions, approval flows, and escalation paths are essential to keep autonomy in check.

Unexpected behaviour in edge cases

Even well-designed agents can struggle with situations that fall outside the norm. Ambiguous requests, incomplete information, or rare scenarios may lead to decisions that technically follow the rules but miss the intent. Without robust testing in real-world conditions, these edge cases tend to surface at the worst possible moment.

Data security and access risks

Agentic AI often needs broad access to data and systems to be effective. That makes security a central concern. If access controls, audit logs, and governance policies are weak, organisations risk exposing sensitive customer, financial, or operational information through automated actions that are hard to trace.

Trust and accountability challenges

For teams to rely on agentic AI, they need to understand how and why decisions are made. If actions cannot be explained or reviewed after the fact, trust erodes quickly. Transparency and accountability are not just technical features, they are critical to long-term adoption.

Taken together, these challenges highlight an important principle: agentic AI should never be treated as a black box. Human oversight, continuous monitoring, and thoughtful design ensure that autonomy enhances performance instead of introducing new sources of risk.

How to approach agentic AI responsibly

To make agentic AI deliver real value, organisations should start with discipline, not ambition.

1. Start from a concrete business outcome

Avoid vague goals like “automate operations.” Instead, define measurable outcomes: reduced cycle time, improved resolution rates, fewer manual interventions.

2. Define clear boundaries

Specify what the agent can and cannot do, which systems it can access, and when human approval is required.

3. Build transparency in

You should be able to understand

why

the agent took a certain action and intervene when necessary.

4. Test in real-world conditions

Messy data, incomplete information, and edge cases are the norm, not the exception. Test agents in realistic scenarios before scaling.

5. Treat agents like team members

Set KPIs, monitor performance, review outcomes, and continuously improve how the agent operates.

Most organisations don’t struggle with AI because they lack tools. They struggle because autonomy, integration, and governance are hard to get right.
