If you’re exploring how agentic AI could work in your organisation,

let’s talk

. Together, we can design AI systems that don’t just assist – they deliver.

title: AI learning: how to upskill your workforce for the digital age
author: Válter
content:
Build a robust AI learning strategy for your organisation. Learn how to implement AI learning programmes, avoid common HR pitfalls, and empower your team to thrive.

The conversation around artificial intelligence has shifted. For business leaders and HR managers, the challenge is no longer just about which software to buy, but how to ensure their people are capable of using it. To remain competitive, modern organisations must move beyond seeing AI as a task for the IT department and start treating AI learning as a core competency for every employee.

In this article, we break down what AI learning means for your workforce, how to structure an effective training programme, why it is critical for modern organisations to stay aligned with reality, and what it takes to implement these systems in a way that delivers lasting value.

Why AI learning literacy is essential

AI learning is less about coding and more about building a deep, functional literacy within your team. It represents the vital shift from a static organisation to one that adaptively improves over time.

Fostering this environment means empowering staff to look past the “black box” of technology and develop a sharp, contextual understanding of what

AI can and cannot achieve

. This literacy ensures that teams don’t just follow automated outputs blindly but instead use their fluency to refine predictions and actions, maintaining a crucial “human-in-the-loop” oversight.

Ultimately, when a team masters the ethics of data quality and the nuances of the learning process, they transition from being mere users of technology to strategic architects of a continuously improving business.

What to include in your AI learning programme

A successful internal training programme doesn’t need to turn your staff into programmers. Instead, your AI learning curriculum should focus on these four pillars:

Demystifying the technology

Explaining how algorithms learn patterns from data rather than just following hard-coded rules.

Prompt engineering and feedback loops

Teaching staff that AI learning depends on feedback; users must know how to signal success or failure to improve outcomes.

Governance in AI learning

Establishing clear ownership and

compliance standards

to manage the complexity of these systems.

Identifying use-cases

Helping employees spot where a learning system can improve accuracy over time compared to traditional, rigid automation.

Common pitfalls in organisational AI learning

When implementing an AI learning strategy, it is easy to fall into the trap of

treating technology as a simple “plug-and-play”

feature rather than a deep organisational capability. This often leads to training that is too technical and lacks the necessary collaboration between HR, leadership, and IT.

Another frequent mistake is

ignoring the data foundations

; even the most enthusiastic team cannot succeed if their learning is built on biased or outdated information.

Perhaps most critically, many organisations fail by

fostering fear instead of curiosity

. If employees feel that AI is a threat to their job security rather than a tool to augment their expertise, they will hesitate to provide the essential feedback that allows these systems to improve, ultimately stalling the organisation’s progress.

Best practices for delivering AI learning to your team

Successful upskilling requires more than just access to tools – it demands a structured approach that prioritises practical results and long-term capability over simple experimentation.

1.    Tailor training through role-specific workshops

Generic training often fails because it lacks immediate relevance. AI learning should be directly mapped to how your business functions day-to-day. For example, while marketing teams focus on trend discovery, operations should focus on process optimisation. By aligning training with specific workflows, employees quickly identify how AI helps them resolve cases or prioritise tasks.

2.    Prioritise hands-on application over theory

The most effective way to understand AI is through real-world interaction. Move away from theoretical lectures and encourage teams to work with actual business data. This allows them to see firsthand how a model builds its “understanding” of patterns. Practical interaction also highlights the critical importance of data freshness, as staff witness how poor inputs immediately lead to poor outputs.

3.    Implement active feedback loops

Teaching staff how to interact with AI is a core pillar of learning. Users must be trained to signal success or failure to the system to improve future outcomes. These feedback loops are what prevent AI from remaining a “static” tool, ensuring that both the software and the people stay aligned with a constantly changing business reality.

4.    Incentivise curiosity to overcome resistance

A major pitfall in AI adoption is fostering fear instead of curiosity. If employees view AI as a threat to job security, they will hesitate to provide the feedback necessary for the system to improve. Leaders must frame

AI as a tool

to augment expertise rather than replace it, encouraging a culture where experimentation is rewarded.

5.    Establish clear governance and ownership

For AI learning to deliver lasting value, there must be clear

compliance standards

and ownership. This involves a collaborative effort between HR, IT, and leadership to manage the complexity of these systems. Establishing these guardrails early ensures that the team’s learning is built on a foundation of data quality and ethical standards.

6.    Audit and refresh data foundations

Even the most enthusiastic team cannot succeed if their learning is built on biased or outdated information. A critical step in any learning programme is teaching the team to master the ethics of data quality. Regular audits of the data being used for training ensure that the AI’s “understanding” remains accurate and aligned with reality.

7.    Promote a “Human-in-the-Loop” mindset

Training must ensure that teams do not follow automated outputs blindly. A key practice is developing the fluency to refine predictions and maintain human oversight. By treating AI as a partner that requires constant validation, the organisation maintains control and ensures that AI outputs are used to make strategic, well-informed decisions.

8.    Identify and document high-impact use cases

Helping employees spot exactly where a learning system can improve accuracy over time is essential. Instead of traditional, rigid automation, teams should be encouraged to identify tasks where AI can learn from business patterns to deliver better results. Documenting these “wins” helps to scale the learning across other departments.

9.    Commit to an ongoing learning process

AI is not a “plug-and-play” feature or software you deploy once and forget. To prevent skills from becoming obsolete, organisations must treat AI literacy as a core, ongoing competency. This requires regular intervals of retraining and refinement to ensure the business remains a “strategic architect” of its own improvement.

Building AI Skills from Within: Our Salesforce AI Learning Initiative

To truly embrace the AI-powered future, we launched an internal initiative focused on strengthening our Salesforce team’s skills in Artificial Intelligence, from both an admin and developer perspective. The goal is to ensure that every team member masters the fundamentals of AI and can apply them practically in their day-to-day work. For our developers, this learning path is mandatory and supported by a buddy system that encourages collaboration, accountability, and shared growth, along with weekly check-ins to exchange progress, insights, and questions.

After three months of structured learning, teams will put theory into practice through a one-month hands-on challenge, culminating in project presentations in March 2026 and a prize for standout contributions. This initiative reflects our belief that adopting AI starts from within — by continuously learning, experimenting, and preparing our people to lead in the AI-driven digital era.

Master AI learning with Near Partner

At

Near Partner

, we help companies design and implement AI learning systems that fit real workflows and deliver measurable impact. From data strategy to governance and continuous improvement, we focus on making AI practical, reliable, and valuable for your organisation.

If you’re ready to move from experimental tools to systems and teams that actually learn and improve over time,

talk to us

. Let’s build an AI-ready business together.

title: Product lifecycle management software: how to do it right
author: Bárbara Basílio
content:
Product Lifecycle Management Software can save you countless hours in team huddles. Here’s how to choose or build one that works for you.

You’ve built a product. But what happens after it launches? Too often, the lifecycle of a product is treated as an afterthought: split across spreadsheets, scattered feedback, and isolated teams. Meanwhile, opportunities slip through, quality suffers – and you waste countless hours trying to catch up.

Product Lifecycle Management software helps companies bring order to the chaos, by connecting people, processes, and data, so products don’t just get made, they get better.

Let’s break down how it works, why it matters, and how to choose a PLM system that actually supports the way your business works.

What Is Product Lifecycle Management?

Product Lifecycle Management (PLM) is how companies keep a clear view and control over a product’s entire journey – from the moment someone sketches the first idea, through designing, testing, building and launching. After that, PLM helps track ongoing updates, support, and eventually, the day the product is retired or replaced.

It connects people from different teams (designers, engineers, marketers, and manufacturers) so they can easily share information and make smarter decisions. Instead of working in separate silos or passing the product like a baton in a relay race, everyone collaborates in one place with up-to-date info.

6 stages of Product Lifecycle Management

From ideation to end-of-like, these are the 6 main steps a Product Lifecycle Management workflow will typically include.

1. Ideation & concept development

Here’s where it all begins: the ideas, the sketches, the “what ifs”. A good Product Lifecycle Management setup helps you capture them, test them, and figure out which ones worth chasing.

What to do:

Collecting feedback, spot market gaps, or run wild with R&D.

Shaping real requirements.

Building early concepts and sanity-check them.

Making sure someone’s going to want (and buy) this thing.

2. Design & engineering

Now things get serious. The product starts to take form (digitally, at least). Designers and engineers create the models, diagrams and BOMs that turn ideas into blueprints.

What it includes

:

Creating clear, version-controlled designs.

Collaborating across teams without endless email loops.

Defining a single place to track every tweak, comment and update.

3. Manufacturing & process planning

Once your designs are approved, it’s time to figure out how to build it properly. This is where Product Lifecycle Management proves its worth, connecting product specs to your factory floor (or suppliers halfway across the world).

What it includes

:

Choosing the right suppliers and materials.

Planning production steps and resources.

Making sure it’s all compliant.

Estimating costs before it’s too late.

4. Product launch & go-to-market

You’re ready to launch. But can your team find the right product details, documentation, marketing assets, and compliance files without pinging five people on Slack? If yes: congrats, you probably have Product Lifecycle Management in place.

What it include

:

Getting everything and everyone launch-ready.

Avoiding delays because someone missed a step.

Coordinating with sales, logistics, and support.

Keeping everything aligned across regions.

5. Support, maintenance & feedback

Once the product’s out there, real life begins.

Customers have questions

. Bugs appear. Features are used in weird ways you didn’t expect. Product Lifecycle Management helps you stay on top of it, and feed that knowledge back into your process.

What it includes:

Creating Instant access to technical info and past updates.

Customer servicing and troubleshooting.

Tracking issues and what you’ve learned from them.

Turning support calls into valuable insights.

6. End-of-life management

All products reach their last season. PLM keeps your offboarding process clean, documented, and not chaotic.

What it includes

Communicating end-of-life plans clearly.

Managing stock and support.

Closing compliance loops.

Making space (and plans) for the next version.

Product Lifecycle Management software benefits

Product Lifecycle Management might sound like something only massive manufacturers care about. But if you’re building anything (software, devices, systems, machinery, even services), PLM could be the thing standing between you and chaos. Here’s why it deserves your attention.

It brings all your teams onto the same page

Product teams, designers, compliance, procurement, sales – they all care about different things. Without PLM software, they’re probably working in silos, using different tools, talking past each other. PLM connects the dots, gives everyone a single source of truth, and finally makes cross-functional work… actually work.

It cuts down mistakes (the expensive kind)

How many products have hit production with the wrong specs? Or shipped with outdated documentation? Or had to be reworked at the last minute? PLM catches these gaps before they become headlines, by controlling versions, sign-offs, and traceability every step of the way.

It keeps compliance and quality in check

Product recalls, failed audits or lost certificates are not great for business. PLM helps manage the mountains of documentation, certifications, and audit trails that come with regulated products or complex supply chains. So, when someone asks “Where’s the proof this is safe?”, you’ve got it.

It captures knowledge (so it doesn’t walk out the door)

People leave. Emails get deleted. Whiteboards get wiped. PLM keeps the valuable thinking, decisions, designs, and lessons learned in one place, so your team’s knowledge doesn’t vanish with every reorg or resignation.

Features of Product Lifecycle Management Solutions

Here’s what reliable PLM software really offers: the essential building blocks that make everything come together seamlessly.

Centralised product data repository.

A single hub for all product-related information: specs, CAD files, BOMs, test data, change requests, and approvals.

Version and change control.

Tracks every revision and design update, with full visibility into what changed, when, and by whom.

Workflow automation.

Customisable processes for design approvals, document sign-offs, and engineering change orders (ECOs).

Bill of Materials (BOM) management.

Structured and multi-level BOM tracking, with real-time updates and linkage to design and production data.

Collaboration tools.

Real-time commenting, file sharing, and user tagging across teams (internal and external).

Document management.

Structured storage and access control for technical files, certifications, and compliance documentation.

Audit trails and traceability.

Complete history of actions, decisions, and changes (critical for regulated industries).

Integration capabilities.

Built-in or API-based connections to CAD tools, ERP systems, CRM platforms, and other core software.

User roles and permissions.

Granular control over who can access, edit, approve, or view each part of the product lifecycle.

Analytics and reporting.

Dashboards and custom reports for tracking project status, timelines, resource usage, and compliance.

Off-the-shelf vs custom-built PLM: what’s right for you?

When choosing a Product Lifecycle Management software, you’ve got two main paths: buy a ready-made tool or build your own. Each has its strengths and its risks. The right choice depends on your business, your workflows, and how much control you really want.

Off-the-shelf: faster start, less flexibility

Pre-built Product Lifecycle Management platforms can get you up and running quickly. They come with tried-and-tested features, support, and documentation. If your needs are fairly standard (or you’re looking to simplify things) this can be a solid option.

Pros:

Faster deployment

Lower upfront cost

Proven functionality

Regular updates and support

Cons:

May not match your workflows exactly

Can be hard to integrate with legacy tools

Limited customisation

Risk of paying for features you don’t use

Custom-built: tailored fit, longer runway

Building your own PLM system means full control. You design it around your people, processes, and products. It takes more time and investment upfront, but if your business is complex or evolving fast, it can pay off big.

Pros:

100% tailored to your way of working

Seamless integration with your existing stack

Scales with your business, not someone else’s roadmap

You own the data, the logic, and the future

Cons:

Higher initial investment

Longer development time

Requires the right tech partner (or internal team)

Ongoing maintenance is on you

In short: if you need a solid system fast and your processes are fairly standard, off-the-shelf might be enough. But if you’re juggling complexity, unique requirements, or big growth plans, custom-built could be the smarter long game.

Choosing the right Product Lifecycle Management Software

The wrong choice can slow everything down and become a pricey regret. But the right one can change how your teams work together and how fast your products get to market. Here’s how to get it right from the start.

1. Map your needs (not just the ideal ones)

Start with the messy reality of how things

actually

work in your company. What’s broken? Where are the bottlenecks? What data lives in someone’s inbox or personal Dropbox? Map your current product workflows, identify the pain points, and be brutally honest. Then ask: what

should

be smoother?

2. Build a cross-functional task force

PLM touches a lot of people. Designers. Engineers. Operations. Marketing. Legal. If you don’t involve them early, your “perfect” tool will miss half the real-world use cases. So, get a small, vocal group of stakeholders from each function. Make them part of the selection team. Let them be brutally honest too.

3. Prioritise integration (PLM doesn’t live alone)

Whatever tool you pick, it must

talk

to the rest of your stack: CAD systems, ERP, CRM, project management tools, whatever you’re using. If it doesn’t

plug in cleanly

, your shiny new Product Lifecycle Management Software will just become another isolated silo with a login no one remembers.

4. Look for configurability

You want something that adapts to your workflow, not a rigid system that demands you bend to it. But there’s a big difference between configurability (good) and heavy customisation (danger zone). Choose a platform that lets you tweak workflows, user permissions and dashboards easily, without needing to call a developer every time.

5. Test it

Don’t settle for a slick demo. Ask for a real trial and get your task force to use it with real tasks and real data. How long does it take to upload a drawing? To manage a change request? To pull a product version history?

6. Check vendor support & roadmap

When choosing a Product Lifecycle Management Software, you’re also choosing a partner. Ask how often the tool is updated. What’s on the roadmap? What support is offered beyond setup? A good PLM vendor will be in it for the long haul.

7. Scale with confidence

Finally, think ahead. Your needs will evolve. Your team will grow. Products will get more complex. Pick a tool that’s

built to scale

, with permissions, storage, and architecture that won’t collapse under your next product line.

Common Product Lifecycle Management Software challenges (and how to overcome them)

Implementing a Product Lifecycle Management Software is rarely a walk in the park. Resistance to change, juggling complex data and making sure everything actually talks to each other are just a few of the bumps along the way. But with the right approach, these challenges can become manageable (and even a bit enjoyable).

Integration with existing systems

Product Lifecycle Management Software works best when it connects flawlessly with your other tools, like ERP, CRM, or supply chain platforms. Off-the-shelf systems can struggle here, creating extra work. Map existing systems, plan integrations carefully, and make sure data flows as it should, so your team doesn’t waste time hunting for information across multiple platforms.

Data migration

Moving years of legacy data into a new Product Lifecycle Management Software can feel like moving house – messy and stressful. We can handle this carefully, ensuring that every file, specification, and record arrives intact and ready to use. Our structured approach keeps your data clean and organised from day one.

User adoption and training

Teams can resist change or get frustrated with new interfaces. That’s why we guide training in a way that makes sense for real workflows, provide ongoing support, and create user-friendly setups that feel intuitive instead of forced.

Customization needs

Finding a Product Lifecycle Management Software that fits perfectly is tricky, to say the least. Too little customization, and it doesn’t match your processes; too much, and complexity skyrockets. The sweet spot is to tailor the system to match your unique workflows while keeping it lean, practical, and easy to manage.

Scalability issues

Many solutions struggle when new products, teams, or data volumes increase. Your system should scale gracefully, handling expansion without slowdowns or disruptions.

How Near Partner can power your Product Lifecycle Management

Making Product Lifecycle Management effective means shaping tools and processes that fit your business like a glove, solving real-world problems without adding complexity.

At

Near Partner

, we build software that fits your way of working, helps your teams communicate better, and gets products out the door faster, without the usual pains.

If juggling your product processes feels like a circus act, we can help you drop some balls and focus on what matters. Want to see how?

Let’s chat

and figure out the best way forward, together.

title: CRM SaaS: what is it and how to pick one
author: Bárbara Basílio
content:
Discover what is a CRM SaaS, why it matters and how its helps businesses uncover new opportunities.

When people hear “CRM,” many still think of endless spreadsheets, clunky interfaces, and a tool that sales teams reluctantly update at the end of the day. But CRM SaaS has evolved into something far more powerful. Today, it’s less about databases and more about driving growth, enabling teams to connect the dots between customer behavior, business strategy, and long-term revenue.

The market for CRM solutions is booming, but not all platforms are created equal. Choosing the right one can redefine how a company interacts with its customers. Discover what CRM SaaS means today and how you can make the most of it.

What CRM SaaS really means today

Imagine knowing exactly which customers are ready to buy again, which leads need a nudge, or which campaigns are driving results. A cloud CRM brings everything together in one place, so marketing, sales, and service teams speak the same language and work toward shared goals.

Because it’s hosted online, CRM SaaS isn’t limited by geography, hardware, or heavy IT investment. It’s a central hub where all customer data, interactions, and processes live, accessible to any authorised team member with an internet connection. In practice, that means one single version of the truth about your clients, whether you’re in sales, marketing, or service.

By automating repetitive tasks and providing a clear view of priorities, teams can focus on what really drives growth, like building relationships, spotting opportunities, and

delivering experiences that keep customers coming back

.

What a good CRM SaaS should offer

The right platform can make a noticeable difference in daily operations, decision-making, and customer relationships. Here’s what to look for.

1. Intuitive and user-friendly interface

A good CRM should feel natural to use. Teams should be able to navigate, update, and extract insights without constant support. The easier it is to use, the more your staff will actually rely on it.

2. Flexibility

Every company works differently. The CRM should adapt to your workflows, not force you into rigid processes. Customisable fields,

dashboards

, and automations allow the platform to fit your specific needs.

3. Real-time data and reporting

Having accurate, up-to-date information is essential. Look for tools that provide clear dashboards, actionable reports, and alerts that help your team act quickly and confidently.

4. Seamless integration with other tools

Your CRM should play nicely with the apps and systems your teams already use, like email, marketing platforms, or finance tools.

Smooth integration

reduces friction and keeps information flowing naturally.

5. Powerful automation

Automation can save time

, but it should simplify rather than complicate. Tasks like reminders, follow-ups, and lead assignments should be smart, easy to adjust, and focused on meaningful actions.

6. Scalability

Your business will grow, and your CRM needs to grow with you. Check that it can handle increased users, more data, and advanced features over time without becoming slow or unwieldy.

7. Reliable support and guidance

Even the best software benefits from human insight. Access to responsive support, training, and practical advice ensures your teams stay confident and make the most of the platform. At

Near Partner

we provide hands-on guidance, helping you configure, optimise, and adapt the CRM to real business needs.

How to implement CRM SaaS: a step-by-step guide

Implementing a CRM SaaS solution can feel like a big leap, but it doesn’t have to be complicated. Here’s a step-by-step guide to make the process practical and rewarding.

1. Define your goals and priorities

Before any software is chosen, get clear on what you want to achieve. Are you aiming to improve lead management, increase repeat sales, or better understand customer behavior? Mapping out priorities ensures the CRM is set up to deliver measurable outcomes, not just store data.

2. Map your customer journey

Even if you avoid the term “

customer journey

,” it’s useful to understand how clients interact with your business. Identify key touchpoints, decision moments, and common pain points. This helps configure the CRM so that it aligns with real-world workflows rather than forcing your team to adapt to the software.

3. Select the right platform and features

CRM SaaS comes in many shapes and sizes. Focus on a solution that fits your current needs while allowing room to grow. Integration capabilities, usability, and reporting options are often more important than fancy features. Remember: the right platform supports your business, not the other way around.

4. Plan for data migration

Clean, structured data

is the backbone of any CRM. Take time to audit existing records, remove duplicates, and standardise formats. A

well-planned migration

avoids frustration and ensures teams can trust the information they see.

5. Engage your teams early

Successful adoption depends on people, not just technology. Involve key users from the start, gather feedback, and show them how the platform will make their work easier. Training should be practical and relevant, demonstrating value in daily tasks rather than abstract features.

6. Configure, test, and iterate

Start with core processes and test them in real scenarios. Don’t try to do everything at once. Iterative configuration allows you to refine workflows, reports, and automations based on actual usage, creating a system that truly supports your teams.

7. Monitor, measure, and improve

Once live, keep an eye on adoption rates, user satisfaction, and business outcomes. CRM SaaS evolves with your company. Regularly review performance, tweak processes, and expand capabilities as your needs grow.

8. Partner for long-term success

A CRM only works if it fits the way your team actually operates.

Near Partner

brings both technical expertise and a practical understanding of business needs. We help

customise Salesforce

to your workflows, make sure integrations run like they should, and provide guidance along the way. The aim is to make your CRM genuinely useful in day-to-day work, while staying flexible as your business grows.

How to get the most from your CRM SaaS

A CRM platform can do a lot, but its impact depends on how you use it beyond the initial setup.

1. Treat CRM as a living system

Data, processes, and customer behaviors change constantly. Review your workflows, dashboards, and automations regularly to keep them relevant. Small tweaks over time prevent the system from becoming outdated or misaligned with your business reality.

2. Focus on insights

It’s easy to track clicks, calls, or meetings. The real value comes from spotting patterns and trends. Encourage your team to use CRM reports to make decisions, anticipate client needs, and discover opportunities before they become obvious.

3. Personalise interactions thoughtfully

CRM allows you to segment and customise interactions at scale. Go beyond generic emails or outreach: use the data to offer clients something genuinely relevant, whether it’s advice, content, or timely support. This creates loyalty without overcomplicating your processes.

4. Encourage collaboration across teams

A CRM works best when everyone contributes and sees the bigger picture. Share insights between sales, marketing, and service teams. Encourage notes, comments, and updates that help colleagues understand client context, turning individual effort into collective intelligence.

5. Keep it simple for adoption

Even after launch, usability is key. Avoid adding unnecessary fields, rules, or automations that slow people down. The more intuitive and human the system feels, the more your team will rely on it rather than work around it.

6. Learn from mistakes quickly

Not every workflow or automation will work perfectly at first. Track what’s effective, what isn’t, and be ready to adjust without hesitation. Viewing the CRM as a tool for experimentation as well as management can uncover efficiencies you didn’t expect.

7. Align metrics with business goals

Don’t get lost in vanity metrics. Make sure the numbers you monitor reflect outcomes that matter: client retention, deal velocity, repeat purchases, or campaign effectiveness. This keeps the CRM tied to real business impact, rather than just activity tracking.

Measuring the success of your CRM SaaS

Here’s how to check if your CRM SaaS is really helping your business achieve tangible outcomes.

Lead-to-deal conversion rate

: out of all the leads you bring in, how many become paying customers? This tells you if your CRM is helping focus on quality, not just quantity.

Average deal cycle

: how long does it take to close a deal from the moment a lead appears? The shorter the cycle, the faster your CRM is driving revenue.

Win rate per sales stage

: where do deals get stuck or lost? This metric highlights the exact points in your pipeline that need attention.

Repeat purchase rate

: are customers coming back for more? A higher percentage shows your CRM is building loyalty, not just one-time wins.

Customer response time

: how quickly do you get back to inquiries? Faster replies often mean happier, more trusting clients.

Customer satisfaction (CSAT or NPS)

: the ultimate reality check: do customers actually enjoy working with you?

Time spent on admin tasks

: is your team busy selling or stuck filling forms? Less admin time equals more time building relationships.

Manual follow-ups avoided

: every automated reminder is one less thing falling through the cracks.

Error rate in customer records

: clean, accurate data avoids costly mistakes and keeps interactions smooth.

Revenue growth

: the big one: is the CRM helping your business grow period over period?

Retention rate

: are you keeping the customers you worked so hard to win? A healthy CRM should make “goodbye” less common.

Campaign effectiveness

: are your marketing campaigns reaching the right people and converting them into leads? This metric shows if your CRM is amplifying your marketing efforts.

Take your CRM SaaS to the next level with Near Partner

Implementing a CRM SaaS is a significant step, but its real value comes from using it in a way that truly fits your business. When your data, processes, and insights come together, it stops being just software and starts being a real part of how you grow, connect with clients, and make decisions that matter.

Working with

Near Partner

means having a team that gets how your business really works. We help

customise Salesforce

and other solutions to your reality, make sure everything integrates smoothly, and stay by your side as your needs evolve. In short, practical support that makes your CRM genuinely useful.

If you’re ready to stop wrestling with tools and start letting your CRM do the heavy lifting, we can help you turn technology into something your team actually loves to use, and something that drives real results.

Get in touch

.

title: Salesforce Winter ’26 release: 10 biggest updates of the year
author: João Reis
content:
Agentforce, Einstein AI, and Data Cloud are all getting massive upgrades. These are the biggest news from Salesforce Winter ’25 release.

Geolocation triggers that automatically notify customers when you arrive at your destination. Real-time support prompts that guide you through conversations with frustrated users. And the foresight to prevent those frustrations from happening in the first place.

These are just a few of the standout features in the

Salesforce Winter ’25 Release

— one of the most important milestones of the year for Salesforce and the companies that rely on it.

Here are 10 unmissable updates — and what they could mean for your business.

1.  Executive level decision making is now possible with AI agents

If previous Salesforce updates gave us smarter assistants,

Agentforce

feels like a leap into executive-grade intelligence. Think of it less as a digital helper and more as a

business partner that anticipates, recommends, and executes within guardrails you define

.

Instead of waiting for instructions,

Agentforce agents

can proactively surface opportunities, like alerting your sales team to a high-value lead about to churn or suggesting the next best action for a service case before it escalates. They’re not limited to Salesforce alone; they can be deployed across different channels, extending their reach into the real workflows where your teams and customers actually operate.

For leaders, this means less manual follow-up and firefighting, and more

predictability, scale, and consistency

in how teams engage with clients. It’s moving from reactive management to proactive strategy, which is something every executive has wished for in moments of operational overload.

2.  AI just got more nuanced than ever (and niche friendly)

With Winter ’26,

Einstein AI

levels up, connecting more deeply with Salesforce Data Cloud. Take

Einstein Data Prism

: beyond segmenting audiences, it also refines them with surgical precision. For a marketing leader, that could mean designing campaigns that actually resonate with micro-segments instead of broad categories. For a sales executive, it could mean surfacing which accounts are warming up and which need intervention (before numbers slip). That shift can redefine how leaders set priorities and allocate resources across the business.

3.  This long awaited updated will make you forget about different data sources

For many leaders, data feels more like a burden than an advantage, scattered across systems, hard to reconcile, and often outdated by the time it reaches the boardroom.

Salesforce’s

Data Cloud

in Winter ’26 directly tackles this challenge, transforming fragmented information into a

single, connected source of truth

.

With

Data Cloud One

, organizations running multiple Salesforce instances can finally consolidate them under one umbrella. That means finance, sales, marketing, and service aren’t working with conflicting numbers anymore. They’re looking at the same, real-time picture of the customer journey. Imagine the power of a quarterly planning meeting where every executive sees consistent, unified insights instead of debating over mismatched reports.

The platform doesn’t stop at internal systems. Enhanced near-real-time connectors (like those to Amazon Redshift) pull external data into the mix, enabling richer analytics and sharper predictions. Combined with Einstein’s intelligence, leaders can uncover which customer behaviors signal loyalty, which indicate churn, and where to focus investment for the biggest impact.

4.  Managing complex accounts is now much more simple

Managing complex accounts often feels like steering a ship through fog. Multiple stakeholders, hidden risks, and shifting priorities make it easy for opportunities to slip away. Winter ’26 unleashed a new version

Sales Cloud

with an array of features to cut through this complexity.

Account Plans

: it is a living strategy document inside Salesforce. It pulls together SWOT analyses, competitive landscapes, and relationship maps, helping teams align on priorities for high-value clients. For executives overseeing multi-million-dollar accounts, this means greater control and visibility over long sales cycles.

Prospecting Center

: uses Data Cloud’s intelligence to surface accounts most likely to engage. Instead of spreading sales efforts thin, leaders can direct teams toward opportunities with the highest return.

Conversation Insights

: now has

Sales Signals

, which detect emerging customer concerns or trending topics from calls and meetings.

Sales Cloud becomes less about record-keeping and more about

forward-looking strategy

. In practice, this helps sales leaders answer the toughest questions with confidence:

Which accounts are truly worth pursuing right now? How should we allocate our best people? Where is the market moving next?

5.  Winter ’26 release is a step closer to effortless automation

With Winter ’26,

Flow Builder

evolves into a true automation engine. The new

event-triggered flows

mean that the system can automatically respond to actions (a customer signing a contract, a lead downloading a whitepaper, or a technician completing a field visit) without anyone needing to click a button.

Even more interesting is the arrival of

Path Experiments

. Think of it as A/B testing for customer journeys inside Salesforce. Leaders can now test different approaches (say, whether a personalized email or a phone call drives faster deal progression) and roll out the winning strategy to the whole team. With Einstein capable of generating formulas on request, even non-technical managers can customize processes without waiting for developer support.

6.  New features for customer support – including for real-time interactions

With Winter ’26,

Service Cloud

introduces intelligence that helps leaders strike the right balance between quality and efficiency.

The new

Service Intelligence

dashboard brings clarity to case management, flagging potential escalations before they spiral.

Case Summaries

, powered by Einstein, give agents concise overviews so they can prioritize and resolve faster. For leaders, this means shorter response times and a clearer understanding of service bottlenecks.

Einstein Article Recommendations

delivers context-specific answers directly to agents during customer conversations. Instead of reinventing the wheel for every support ticket, agents are armed with the best solutions instantly, reducing costs while improving satisfaction scores.

7.  Field Service apps just got a major boost

For organizations that rely on mobile or remote teams, operational complexity often happens far from HQ. Winter ’26 gives

Field Service

the intelligence to keep field operations smooth and reliable.

With

geolocation-triggered flows

, the system can automatically log a technician’s arrival at a site, send the customer a notification, or initiate a follow-up process. And all without human input. This reduces administrative friction and ensures accuracy in reporting.

The new

hierarchical asset view

adds another layer of efficiency. Technicians can now see parent-child relationships between assets directly on their mobile device, making troubleshooting faster and reducing repeat visits. For leaders, this translates into higher first-time fix rates, happier customers, and lower operational costs.

8.  Better, faster websites and collaboration

As customer and partner ecosystems expand, leaders need platforms that foster collaboration without slowing things down. Winter ’26 strengthens

Experience Cloud

to deliver exactly that.

With

Enhanced Sites

, companies can upgrade existing environments to gain flexible content management, SEO-optimized URLs, and partial deployments. That means faster rollouts, better discoverability, and more control over how brand presence evolves online.

Meanwhile,

Partner Connect

takes partnership collaboration to a new level. By allowing partners to see shared records and real-time updates, it removes friction in joint deals and projects. For executives, this means fewer missed opportunities, stronger alliances, and greater transparency in critical business relationships.

9.  Simpler content creation and catalogue management

Growth means doing more, but smarter. Winter ’26 expands

Marketing Cloud

and

Revenue Cloud

to give leaders tools that scale without diluting quality.

In

Marketing Cloud

, Einstein now supports

multilingual content creation and automated translations

, helping global brands stay consistent across regions without draining resources. Event-based campaign templates make it easier to launch campaigns triggered by customer actions, ensuring relevance and timeliness.

Revenue Cloud

continues its evolution into a central hub for sales and revenue processes. With enhancements to CPQ and product catalogue management, it streamlines the way companies configure, price, and sell. For executives, this means faster deal cycles and more predictable revenue streams.

10.  Better handling of sensitive data

Finally, in an era where trust is as valuable as innovation, Winter ’26 puts

security at the forefront

. The

Privacy Center

now offers stronger data retention and masking policies, ensuring

compliance

with global standards like GDPR. Leaders can rest easier knowing that sensitive data is being managed responsibly.

Additionally, Salesforce has connected

Event Monitoring

to Data Cloud, allowing real-time analysis of system performance and user behavior. For IT and compliance leaders, this provides a proactive layer of oversight that spots irregularities early and strengthens governance without slowing down the business.

Explore the full potential of Salesforce with Near Partner

What makes Salesforce Winter ’26 remarkable is not just the technology itself, but the way it opens new doors for organizations willing to rethink how they engage customers, manage data, and scale operations. Features like Agentforce or Data Cloud can sound futuristic, but in the hands of the right teams, they quickly translate into sharper decisions, faster execution, and measurable growth.

However, the truth is that anyone can read the release notes. The real challenge is knowing what matters for

your

business and ignoring the rest. That’s the

Near Partner

mindset: practical ways to translate Salesforce updates into everyday wins that your teams and your clients will actually feel.

Winter ’26 hands you a powerful toolbox, but what really matters is knowing which tool to grab, when to use it, and how to make it stick inside your business. That’s the journey worth taking. And it starts with choosing the right guide: Near Partner.

title: Nearshore: what it is, how it works, and how to start
author: Bárbara Basílio
content:
Find out what nearshore is, how it helps businesses and how to implement in your company.

Tight deadlines, stretched teams, and growing pressure to deliver more — faster. Sound familiar?

If you need to scale without losing control (or sleep),

nearshoring

could be the strategy you’ve been overlooking.

In this guide, we break down what nearshore really means, how it works in practice, and how to get started — the smart way.

What is nearshore?

Nearshoring means moving your software development or service operations to a nearby country – usually within the same or similar time zone – instead of offshoring to a far-flung destination.

The idea is simple: keep the benefits of outsourcing (access to talent, lower costs, scalability), but remove the friction that often comes with geographical and cultural distance.

Simply put, it’s choosing partners who are easier to collaborate with, who understand your market context, and who can move fast without getting lost in translation.

Why nearshoring works: the key advantages

From collaboration to cultural fit, these are the main benefits of nearshoring.

1. Real-time collaboration

Working in overlapping time zones means you’re not stuck waiting overnight for answers. Teams can meet, debug, adjust and iterate — all within the same working day. That kind of fluidity cuts down project delays and reduces miscommunication.

2. Cultural proximity that makes teamwork natural

Nearshore partners often share similar working hours, business culture, and expectations — which makes a huge difference when you need aligned decisions and fewer unnecessary back-and-forths.

3. Lower operational risk

When you’re working with nearshore partners, you’re often within similar legal, regulatory and data protection frameworks (think GDPR, for example). This means less compliance friction, clearer contracts, and more control over how your data and projects are handled.

4. Top-tier talent

Nearshore regions are packed with qualified developers, designers, and engineers — many of whom have worked with international teams before. You get access to serious skills, fresh perspectives, and reliable delivery — without the premium costs of hiring in London, New York or Berlin.

How to choose a nearshore location

Choosing a nearshore location is a strategic decision, because where your nearshore team is based will directly impact the quality of collaboration, the speed of delivery, and the overall experience. So, what should guide your decision?

1. Cultural compatibility

It goes far beyond shared languages or time zones. You want to work with teams that understand your way of doing things: how you approach deadlines, feedback, autonomy, even meetings. When there’s alignment in how people work and think, everything moves faster and with fewer misunderstandings.

2. Time zone overlap that actually works

Look for at least 3 or 4 hours of shared working time. This allows for live standups, daily check-ins, or quick problem-solving without scheduling headaches. Too much overlap, however, might mean you’re just recreating an in-house team abroad, which defeats the point of flexible scaling.

3. Access to qualified, experienced talent

Nearshore only works if the local talent pool is deep and mature. That means professionals with solid technical backgrounds, experience in cross-border teams, and the ability to work independently.

4. Strong digital and business infrastructure

High-speed connectivity, access to modern collaboration tools, and a tech-friendly environment are essential. A place with reliable digital infrastructure reduces operational friction and helps external teams feel more like an extension of your own.

5. Legal, economic, and data security stability

Make sure the location has clear legal frameworks for data protection, IP rights, and service contracts. You want to work with teams based in countries that offer predictability, especially for long-term projects.

6. Supportive ecosystem

Some locations – Portugal being a great example – have invested in creating environments that attract international tech business. That includes accelerator programs, developer communities, and government incentives that indirectly benefit you as a client.

How to choose a nearshore partner

A nearshore partner becomes part of your

extended team

. So, the stakes are higher. You’re trusting them to deliver and also to think with you, keep the momentum going, and help you move faster without compromising quality.

1. Track record with similar projects

Ask what they’ve actually built. Look for

case studies

, production-ready work, and long-term collaborations that show they can scale, adapt, and stay aligned through evolving priorities. Bonus points if they’ve worked with companies of your size and pace.

2. Communication that feels like collaboration

Do they really listen? Do they challenge when it makes sense? Are their answers thoughtful, clear, and free of buzzwords? From the first call, communication should feel easy, not effortful. You should never have to “decode” their emails or wait three days for an answer.

3. Senior talent involved early on

The best partners bring experienced people to the table from day one. You’ll need help to shape realistic plans, get suggestions of better approaches, and get the delivery that actually match the promises.

4. Process transparency

You don’t need a 100-page methodology. But you

do

need to know how they work, how they estimate, how they handle scope changes, how progress is tracked, and how risks are flagged early. Clarity here avoids nasty surprises later.

5. Technical alignment and standards

Your tech stack matters. But so do standards, security protocols, and dev practices. Your partner should be used to working with CI/CD pipelines, version control, automated testing, and should never need chasing for documentation or clean handovers.

6. A mindset of ownership

You’ll spot this quickly: teams who ask the right questions, challenge vague specs, think beyond the ticket, and genuinely care if what’s being built will work for your users. That’s not extra, that’s what makes a real partner.

5 signs nearshore is for you

Not every company is ready to nearshore, but many wait longer than they should. If you’re seeing some of these signs, it’s probably time to start the conversation.

1. Your internal team is stretched too thin

Projects are piling up, delivery is lagging, and even small improvements get pushed down the priority list. You don’t need more hands; you need a smart extension of your team that can move with you.

2. You want to scale, but not blindly

Hiring full-time can feel like a big leap, especially if you’re unsure of the long-term workload. Nearshoring gives you the flexibility to scale up fast, without locking into overhead.

3. You’re looking for better collaboration, not just cheap execution

Offshoring didn’t quite work. Time zones made sync impossible. Communication felt transactional. You want people who work close to your hours, think with you, and actually feel part of the process.

4. You’ve got a clear roadmap and a growing backlog

You know what needs to be built. You even have specs. But capacity keeps getting in the way. Nearshoring can help you execute faster, without derailing your core team’s focus.

5. You care about long-term value, not just short-term fixes

You’re not just

outsourcing

a one-off feature. You’re investing in something that needs to evolve, scale, and integrate well over time. For that, you need continuity, and a partner who’s in it for more than a sprint.

5 signs nearshore may not be for you

Nearshoring isn’t a fit for every team, and knowing that early can save time, budget, and frustration.

1. Your product or tech direction isn’t clear yet

If you’re still figuring out what to build or how to build it, a nearshore team might not be the right move just yet. They can bring speed and expertise but not replace core product vision or leadership.

2. Your internal processes are barely holding together

If collaboration tools, code management, or task tracking are chaotic (or non-existent), adding more people (even great ones) will only multiply the friction.

3. You treat external teams as vendors, not partners

Nearshoring works best with shared ownership. If you’re only looking for a task executor rather than someone to contribute to your product’s evolution, this model might fall short.

4. You’re not ready to invest in integration

This isn’t plug-and-play. Nearshoring requires intentional onboarding, open communication, and commitment from both sides. If you’re not willing (or able) to prioritise that, it won’t deliver what it could.

5. You expect full results on day one

There’s always a ramp-up period. If you’re not open to some initial adaptation on processes, communication rhythms, or expectations, nearshoring may feel like it’s “not working,” when really it just needed space to click.

How to get started with nearshoring

With the right steps, you can build a nearshore setup that feels aligned, efficient and easy to manage. Here’s how to move forward.

1. Define what you need

Start by mapping out which parts of your operations could benefit from nearshoring. This could be software development, QA, design, customer support or even data management. Don’t aim to move everything at once. Be specific and realistic. Focus on roles or functions where quality, availability of talent, and time zone alignment can make a clear difference.

2. Research the best-fit region

Price matters, but it’s not the only factor, or even the most important one. Look at regions where there’s a solid talent pool, good infrastructure, strong education systems, and cultural compatibility with your team.

3. Choose a partner that aligns with your rhythm

You want a working relationship that flows. That means

looking for a partner

who understands your industry, has a proven track record, and can adjust to your processes and tools. Pay attention to how they communicate, how quickly they respond, and how they approach problem-solving.

4. Start with a focused pilot

Before going all in, set up a small engagement: a short project, an MVP, or a few key roles. This gives you the chance to validate the collaboration, see how communication plays out, and refine your internal workflows. It’s a low-risk way to test the waters and get real insights into how the setup performs in practice.

5. Build for long-term success

Once the foundation is working, prepare to scale. Standardise your onboarding, set up clear expectations around deliverables and communication, and invest in integrating the team into your

company culture

. Nearshoring works best when the external team feels like part of the internal one, instead of a separate unit.

Looking for a nearshore partner that actually feels close?

At

Near Partner

, we’re close on the map – based in Portugal – but even closer in mindset, responsiveness, and the way we collaborate. We’re a boutique software house offering outsourcing and nearshore solutions, with a growing team of talented developers fluent in a wide range of technologies: from tried-and-tested languages like C++, Java, Python, and Ruby, to modern low-code platforms like Outsystems and Salesforce.

Let’s build something solid together

, with real connection, clear communication and momentum that doesn’t fade.

title: Custom software: is it time to build your own?
author: Bárbara Basílio
content:
Has the time come to build your own custom software rather than relying on off-the-shelf solutions? Here’s how to make the call.

Choosing to build custom software for your business was never going to be an easy decision.

Take project management, for example. You probably started by browsing the usual suspects—Trello, Asana, Monday.com. Maybe you even tried patching the problem with a purpose-built Google Sheet. (At least it’s free, right?)

If you’re more technically inclined, you may have experimented with custom dashboards—or, if the budget allowed, explored premium ecosystems from Salesforce or Microsoft.

Yet for many business and IT leaders, this decision-making process ends up feeling overwhelming.

Some tools are too rigid, others too open-ended. Some pack in far more features than any team will ever use (yet still pay for), while others are so bare-bones they require a stack of extra tools just to fill the gaps.

So… when is the right moment to build your own solution? What are the tell-tale signs that it’s worth investing the time and money, instead of adapting an off-the-shelf product?

Here’s what you need to know to make the call.

What custom software really means

Custom software is exactly what it sounds like: software built specifically for your business, not adapted from someone else’s.

Unlike off-the-shelf solutions,

custom software

is designed around how your organisation. It doesn’t ask you to change processes to match the tool; it adapts to you, creating a layer of intelligence that unifies different platforms and workflows.

For companies trying to connect several systems, that flexibility is crucial. Each system speaks its own language, and custom software is what makes them understand each other, securely, efficiently, and in real time.

The benefits of custom software

Custom software gives businesses something off-the-shelf tools rarely can: a perfect fit. Instead of forcing your team to adapt to rigid features or workarounds, custom solutions are designed around your exact workflows, goals, and constraints. The result is a system that feels intuitive from day one, reduces friction across teams, and scales naturally as the business grows—without piling on plugins, hacks, or extra subscriptions.

It also provides a strategic edge. With complete control over functionality, integrations, and data, businesses can innovate faster, automate more processes, and build digital experiences competitors simply can’t replicate. Custom software becomes an asset—not just a tool—supporting productivity, efficiency, and long-term differentiation in ways pre-packaged platforms are rarely able to match.

One of its biggest advantages is the ability to integrate deeply with your existing systems. Custom software can seamlessly connect PLM, ERP, CRM and even IoT devices, creating a unified operational backbone that off-the-shelf tools struggle to match. This level of integration turns software from a cost centre into a strategic asset that drives innovation across the organisation.

Limitations of Custom Software

Despite the advantages, custom software isn’t always the right solution. It typically requires a higher upfront investment—both in budget and time—compared to off-the-shelf tools. The development process involves discovery, design, testing, iterations, and ongoing maintenance, which means your team needs the bandwidth and commitment to stay involved. For businesses needing something immediate, predictable, or low-cost, this can be a significant hurdle.

Custom solutions also introduce long-term responsibility. While ready-made tools handle updates, bug fixes, security patches, and new features automatically, custom software requires dedicated support—either internal or external. Without proper maintenance, even a great system can become outdated or vulnerable. It’s a powerful option, but one that works best when the organization is ready to invest not just in building the software, but in sustaining it.

When to Build Custom Software

Deciding whether to build custom software comes down to understanding your needs, your resources, and your long-term strategy. While it’s a powerful investment, it only pays off when certain conditions are in place. Here are the key factors to consider before making the call:

You have (or can maintain) the right technical support

Custom software isn’t a one-and-done project—it requires ongoing maintenance, updates, and improvements. If you have an internal technical team, even a small one, you’re already in a strong position. And even if your team isn’t large enough to handle everything, combining internal oversight with an external development partner often gives you the best of both worlds: expertise, flexibility, and long-term stability.

Your business has needs that off-the-shelf tools can’t meet

If your workflows are unique, your processes highly specific, or your integration needs more complex than what standard tools offer, custom software becomes a strategic advantage. It lets you build exactly what your team needs—no workarounds, no compromises, no unnecessary features. The more tailored your operations, the more custom software pays for itself.

You can turn the software into an asset for customers

Custom software becomes even more valuable when it’s not just for internal use, but something your customers can interact with directly. Whether it’s a client portal, scheduling system, dashboard, or even a white-label product, software that enhances the customer experience becomes a long-term competitive asset and can even open new revenue streams.

You have the budget for development and ongoing maintenance

Building custom software requires a higher upfront investment than subscribing to an off-the-shelf tool. Beyond development, you need to factor in ongoing hosting, improvements, and fixes. If your budget allows for both the build and the upkeep, custom software can deliver a strong return. If not, a hybrid solution or customization on top of an existing platform may be a better first step.

Off-the-shelf tools are becoming too expensive or limiting

Sometimes the cost of multiple licenses, add-ons, integrations, and overlapping tools ends up exceeding the price of building your own system. Or, the limitations of commercial tools—rigid workflows, missing features, expensive upgrades—start slowing you down. When the cumulative cost (financial or operational) keeps rising, custom software often becomes the more efficient option.

You have the time to build properly

Custom software takes time. Discovery, design, development, testing, and iteration all require patience and alignment across your team. If you need something operational tomorrow, off-the-shelf tools may be the only realistic option. But if you’re planning ahead and can allocate the months needed to design something meaningful, custom software sets you up for a more scalable, sustainable solution.

Your team is relying on too many manual workarounds

If employees are spending hours copying data between tools, exporting spreadsheets, updating trackers, or improvising processes that software should handle, it’s a strong signal that existing tools are failing. Custom software can automate repetitive tasks and eliminate friction that hurts productivity.

Your current tool stack is becoming too fragmented

When you need five—or fifteen—different apps to handle what should be a single workflow, complexity explodes. If integrations are brittle, data gets duplicated, and onboarding becomes painful, a consolidated custom system can fix the root problem rather than treat symptoms.

Data lives in too many places (and you can’t trust it)

If your data is scattered across platforms and never fully accurate or up to date, custom software can centralize it. Reliable, real-time data is often reason enough to build a tailored solution—especially when reporting matters to leadership or customers.

Security, compliance, or privacy requirements are too specific

Regulated industries (healthcare, finance, HR, legal, etc.) often discover that generic tools don’t meet their obligations. If you need strict access controls, audit logs, encryption, or industry-specific compliance, custom software lets you design these protections exactly as required.

your business model is evolving faster than your tools

When your company is innovating—adding services, new operational models, or more complex customer flows—off-the-shelf tools rarely keep up. If your software is slowing innovation rather than enabling it, that’s a tell-tale sign it’s time to build something that grows with you.

You need a competitive differentiator

If software is central to how you deliver value—operations, customer service, product experience—it shouldn’t be generic. Custom software lets you build capabilities competitors can’t buy or replicate. If differentiation matters, custom is often the only real option.

The ROI of Custom Software

Calculating the ROI of custom software starts with understanding two sides of the equation:

what it costs to build and maintain

, and

what it saves or earns for the business over time

. On the cost side, you’ll want to factor in the full development lifecycle—discovery, design, engineering, testing, deployment—as well as ongoing hosting and maintenance. You should also include the opportunity cost of your internal team’s time, plus any external partners supporting the project. Add all of this together, and you have your

Total Cost of Ownership

(TCO).

On the revenue side, ROI comes from two sources:

savings

(what the software eliminates or reduces) and

gains

(what the software enables). Savings can include fewer subscription fees, reduced manual work, faster workflows, fewer errors, lower customer support workload, or decreased operational costs. Gains come from improved conversion rates, higher customer satisfaction, new features that drive upsell, faster service delivery, or entirely new revenue streams if the software becomes customer-facing. Once you quantify these improvements—monthly or yearly—you can calculate ROI using a simple formula:

ROI = (Financial Gains – Total Cost of Ownership) / Total Cost of Ownership

The more accurately you track time saved, tools replaced, revenue generated, and efficiencies gained, the clearer the business case becomes.

How long does it take to build custom software?

The timeline for building custom software depends largely on the complexity of the solution, the number of features, and how many systems it needs to integrate with. Simple tools—like internal dashboards, automations, or lightweight workflow apps—can often be built in

4 to 12 weeks

. Mid-sized platforms with multiple user roles, advanced features, or integrations with systems like ERP, PLM, or CRM typically require

3 to 6 months

. Large-scale platforms, customer-facing portals, or IoT-connected systems can take

6 to 12+ months

, often delivered in phases so teams can start using key functionality earlier.

What matters most is that development isn’t a single block of work—it’s a sequence. The process usually includes discovery and scoping, UX/UI design, development, testing, deployment, and ongoing iterations based on user feedback. Well-managed projects follow agile delivery, meaning new features are released continuously rather than waiting for a “big launch.” This approach allows businesses to see value sooner while reducing risk and ensuring the final product genuinely matches how teams work.

Building custom software with AI: what to expect

AI-assisted development and vibe coding can dramatically accelerate how software gets built. One of the biggest advantages is speed: teams can turn ideas into prototypes in hours instead of weeks. AI helps generate interfaces, suggest workflows, write boilerplate code, and automate testing — reducing repetitive work and lowering initial development costs.

Vibe coding also makes early collaboration easier, since stakeholders can express what they want in natural language rather than technical specifications. It’s an excellent way to explore ideas, validate concepts faster, and keep development closely aligned with the product’s intended experience.

But vibe coding has limitations — and this is where expert support becomes essential. AI can generate impressive starting points, but it can’t replace careful architecture, security practices, compliance, or long-term maintainability.

Without experienced developers guiding the process, AI-generated code can quickly become inconsistent, inefficient, or fragile. Integrations with ERP, PLM, CRM or IoT systems still require deep technical judgement, and scaling a product safely requires the kind of engineering discipline AI can’t replicate. Vibe coding accelerates the journey, but human expertise ensures the software is robust, secure, and ready for real-world use.

Near Partner: making custom software work for your whole business

At

Near Partner

our approach blends strategy, engineering, and delivery:

Integration strategy

to map how information and decisions should flow across your existing systems.

Custom development

to build connectors, APIs, and orchestration layers tailored to how your business operates.

Cloud and data expertise

to ensure security, performance, and scalability.

Continuous support and optimisation

to evolve integrations as your business grows.

See your systems finally talking to each other, and watch your business run smoother than ever with custom software.

Start the conversation with Near Partner today
