title: Risk sharing model for development projects: what it is and is it right for you
author: Sérgio
content:
Risk sharing is redefining what partnership means: shared responsibility, shared results, shared growth. Learn what it is and how it works.

Every company talks about partnership. Fewer are willing to test what that word really means. In most collaborations, one side takes all financial risk while the other collects predictable fees, regardless of the outcome. Risk sharing challenges that imbalance. It ties success to measurable results and places both sides on equal footing. In this model, accountability becomes real. Discover what risk sharing really means, what to watch out for, and how to make it work in practice.

What is the risk sharing model for development projects?

Risk sharing is the grown-up version of collaboration. It happens where partners stop pretending every deal is risk-free and start admitting that uncertainty is part of doing real business.

At its core, risk sharing means exactly what it says: dividing risk between parties so everyone has skin in the game. When done right, it aligns incentives, builds trust, and turns “supplier-client” dynamics into something closer to co-ownership of outcomes. You win together, or you fix it together.

Let’s say a manufacturing company was struggling with slow production cycles and recurring equipment failures, so they partner with a tech firm to implement a predictive maintenance system. Instead of a traditional supplier contract, they set up a risk-sharing model. Both sides agreed on clear performance metrics before the project started – say 15% reduction in unplanned downtime. To make it fair, the tech firm absorbed 30% of the implementation cost upfront. In return, they would receive a performance bonus if the targets were met, or a smaller fixed fee if not.

Throughout the project, data from sensors and production reports was shared in real time, giving both teams full visibility of performance. At month four, let’s say that downtime had dropped 19%. The bonus was triggered automatically, and the partnership extended to new production lines.

This approach is gaining traction because businesses are tired of transactional partnerships that collapse the moment things get unpredictable. In a world where tech moves faster than contracts, sharing risk is how you stay agile without losing control.

Traditional models vs. risk sharing: a different kind of partnership

Most business relationships still follow a familiar script: one side provides a service or product, the other pays for it, and success is measured by delivery, instead of the real impact achieved. It’s neat, predictable, and in theory, “safe.” But it often creates a false sense of security.

In traditional models, risk sits unevenly on one side. The client shoulders the uncertainty of whether the solution will truly deliver, while the supplier focuses on fulfilling the contract as written. Everyone stays in their lane, but no one’s really driving toward the same destination.

Risk sharing flips that dynamic. Instead of separating responsibilities, it fuses them. Both parties contribute to (and are affected by) the same outcomes. It’s a shift from

transactional

to

relational

, from

delivery

to

performance

, and from

protecting interests

to

growing them together

.

Here’s how they diverge in practice:

Aspect

Traditional Model

Risk-Sharing Model

Focus

Deliverables and deadlines

Outcomes and value created

Risk Distribution

Mostly on the client or end user

Shared proportionally between partners

Incentives

Supplier paid regardless of success

Rewards tied to measurable impact

Transparency

Limited to contract scope

Continuous and open exchange of data

Flexibility

Low – predefined terms

High – adaptable to evolving needs

Relationship

Transactional

Collaborative and long-term

Some may think that risk sharing replaces traditional models, but we like to think it elevates them. It takes the structure and discipline of conventional agreements and layers them with a sense of shared purpose. Instead of protecting each side from risk, it connects them through it

Benefits of the risk sharing model

When businesses start thinking in terms of shared outcomes instead of isolated responsibilities, something powerful happens. Here’s why the smartest partnerships are built around it.

1. Real commitment

When both sides have something at stake, effort stops being performative. Everyone’s pulling in the same direction, not because they are supposed to, but because success is genuinely mutual. That kind of alignment turns abstract KPIs into shared goals.

2. More transparency

Risk sharing pushes both sides to open up about costs, dependencies, and performance metrics early on. It creates a culture of honesty that prevents the usual finger-pointing when challenges appear.

3. Flexibility to adapt

Traditional contracts lock partners into rigid terms that age quickly. Risk-sharing models, on the other hand, are designed to evolve. They make room for real-time adjustments.

4. Shared innovation

When risk is shared, teams are more willing (or pushed) to test, iterate, and explore new approaches. That’s often where the best breakthroughs emerge, in the space where both sides are invested in finding a better way.

5. Stronger long-term relationships

Partnerships built on shared risk tend to last longer because they’re based on understanding. When both parties have weathered challenges together, the bond becomes less transactional and more strategic. And that’s where real collaboration lives.

How risk sharing works in practice

It’s one thing to agree that sharing risk makes sense, but it’s another to bake it into a partnership. The essence of a good risk-sharing model lies in design: clear rules, measurable outcomes, and mutual trust that’s proven.

1. Define what “success” looks like

Before any contract is signed, both sides need to agree on what success looks like and how it will be measured. It might be

efficiency gains

, cost savings, performance improvements, or new business generated. The clearer the definition, the fairer the distribution of rewards and responsibilities.

2. Map the risks and who owns which part

Some risks relate to execution, others to market shifts, technology, or

compliance

. The goal is to assign them to the partner best equipped to manage each one. That’s where expertise replaces assumption.

3. Link value to performance

This is where theory becomes tangible. With risk sharing, payment or reward structures are tied directly to outcomes. It could be through gain-sharing, milestone bonuses, or variable fees linked to results. When performance improves, both sides benefit. If it falls short, both adjust.

4. Keep feedback constant

Risk sharing thrives on continuous feedback, like regular reviews, transparent data, and open discussion. That’s what allows both sides to adapt quickly when conditions change and to keep momentum when they don’t.

5. Build it into culture

The most successful models go beyond paperwork. They embed shared responsibility into daily operations: how teams communicate (even

extended teams

), how problems are solved, and how success is celebrated. Once that mindset takes root, collaboration becomes a second nature.

How to reduce the risk in the risk sharing model

When managed well, risk becomes part of the design instead of a problem to be solved. Here’s hot to approach it.

1. Start with shared visibility

Everyone involved (from client stakeholders to delivery teams) should see the same numbers, progress, and constraints. Shared visibility keeps decisions grounded in facts, and helps avoid the classic “we thought you meant…” moments that derail projects.

2. Break progress into measurable cycles

Instead of one long road to delivery, projects are divided into smaller checkpoints with tangible outcomes. Each cycle validates assumptions, provides early indicators of performance, and allows quick adjustments before small issues grow into structural risks.

3. Keep KPIs alive

Keep project KPI active, reviewed, and transparent throughout the project so both sides can anticipate shifts in performance and act before they become problems.

4. Align business and technical priorities

Risk often appears in the gap between what the business expects and what’s being built. Continuous dialogue between decision-makers and delivery teams keeps priorities synced, reducing the chance of misaligned outcomes.

Risk sharing with Near Partner

At

Near Partner

, we approach risk sharing as a framework for measurable success. We start by defining the project scope and business objectives together. From there, we establish KPIs and a baseline, as the foundation for clarity.

Once the project is in motion, we monitor results over a 3-to-6-month window, validate impact jointly, and activate the reward model when targets are met. It’s a simple equation: shared commitment, shared gain.

If that sounds like the kind of partnership your organisation needs,

let’s start the conversation

.

title: Salesforce Audit: what is it, why do it and what you can learn from it
author: Bárbara Basílio
content:
Find out how a Salesforce Audit helps you fix what slows you down and make your CRM work the way your business does.

It usually starts quietly. A new field here, a quick automation there. Someone adds a report to track a new metric, another person customises a dashboard “just for now.” Months later, the system that once felt sharp and intuitive starts to feel cluttered. Data doesn’t line up. Teams complain that Salesforce is slowing them down instead of helping them move faster.

That’s when most companies realise something’s off, but few can pinpoint exactly what. Is it the data? The automations? The way people are using it?

That’s where a Salesforce Audit proves its worth. It’s a focused way to uncover what’s working, what’s not, and how to make your CRM perform the way it was meant to.

If you’ve ever felt that Salesforce could be doing more for your business, keep reading. This might be the most useful check-up your organisation can do.

What is a Salesforce Audit?

A Salesforce Audit is a deep dive into how your Salesforce works for you. It looks at how your teams use it, where data gets stuck, and whether your setup still matches the way your business actually operates today.

Over time, Salesforce tends to collect “digital clutter”: extra fields, old automations, unused reports, custom objects nobody remembers creating. The audit clears that noise, exposes what’s slowing you down, and shows you where the platform can

start working for you again

, instead of the other way around.

It’s part detective work, part optimisation, and part strategy session. The goal is to make Salesforce easier to use, more insightful, and perfectly tuned to your goals.

Why do a Salesforce Audit?

In short, because Salesforce is never really “done.” It keeps evolving with new users, new processes, new automations. What once made sense can slowly turn into something nobody quite controls. A Salesforce Audit helps you step back and see the full picture.

Identify inefficiencies

Small inefficiencies pile up quietly:

duplicate data

,

workflows

that trigger twice, manual steps that could be automated. An audit highlights where effort is being wasted and how to make Salesforce simpler, faster, and cleaner.

Increase adoption

If your team finds Salesforce confusing, they’ll avoid it. An audit helps uncover what’s getting in their way, like cluttered layouts or irrelevant fields, so you can design an experience people actually want to use.

Ensure compliance and security

User permissions and data access tend to drift over time. A structured audit brings visibility into who can see what, ensuring your

data stays protected

and

compliant

with internal and external standards.

When should you run an audit?

There’s no “perfect” time, but there are definitely moments when a Salesforce Audit can make all the difference. The truth is, most companies wait until frustration builds up. The best ones don’t. They treat an audit as part of staying sharp.

1. When Salesforce starts to feel heavy

If your team says Salesforce is “slow,” “messy,” or “not worth the effort,” it’s time. These are usually signs of cluttered data, redundant automations, or confusing processes that have quietly accumulated.

2. Before you scale

Growth amplifies everything, good and bad. If you’re expanding teams, entering new markets, or launching new products, an audit ensures your foundation is solid before you build on it.

3. When reports stop telling the truth

If

dashboards

no longer match what’s happening on the ground, you’re probably looking at inconsistent data or misaligned metrics. An audit gets your reporting back to reality.

4. Ahead of a major integration or upgrade

Planning to connect Salesforce with another platform, or move to a newer version? Auditing first helps you clean the house, avoid

technical debt

, and make the transition seamless instead of chaotic.

5. As routine maintenance

Just like you wouldn’t drive a car for years without a service, you shouldn’t let Salesforce run unchecked. A yearly or biannual audit keeps performance high, data healthy, and users happy.

Types of Salesforce audits

Not every business needs the same kind of audit. Sometimes you need a deep technical clean-up; other times, you just need clarity on how people are using the platform. The best approach depends on what’s holding you back, but here are the main types to consider.

Data Audit

A Salesforce data audit uncovers duplicates, outdated records, and inconsistent formats that undermine your reporting and decision-making. The goal is simple: rebuild trust in your data so every number tells the truth.

Security & Access Audit

As teams grow, permissions often drift, leaving data exposed or users with access they no longer need. This audit reviews roles, profiles, and sharing rules to ensure your information stays protected, without slowing down collaboration.

Configuration Audit

Salesforce setups tend to bloat. Custom fields, workflows, validation rules, triggers, all added with good intentions, but not always with long-term structure. A Configuration Audit identifies what’s essential, what’s redundant, and how to streamline everything for efficiency and clarity.

Performance Audit

If Salesforce feels sluggish or processes take too long, a Performance Audit digs into what’s behind it, The result: faster load times, smoother user experience, and more responsive dashboards.

Adoption & Experience Audit

Even the most advanced setup fails if people don’t use it. This audit focuses on behaviour, meaning how teams actually interact with Salesforce day-to-day. It uncovers friction points, training gaps, and UX issues that affect adoption and productivity.

Most companies benefit from a mix of these. A well-rounded Salesforce Audit doesn’t fix isolated issues, but it helps you see how every part of the system connects, so you can create a

CRM that’s powerful and genuinely enjoyable to use

.

Salesforce Audit: the Near Partner way

If you suspect your Salesforce could be doing more for you, you’re probably right. And we can show you exactly how.

Our approach starts with understanding your business context: what’s working, what’s slowing you down, and where you want to go. Then we bring in our

Salesforce Diagnostic Tool

, a free proprietary audit that analyses your configuration, automations, data quality, and user behaviour. It highlights inefficiencies, redundancies, and risks, giving us a clear picture of where value is leaking.

From there, we don’t hand you a 200-page report and say “good luck”. We deliver a ranked list of issues (what needs fixing now, what can wait), practical steps you can act on, organised by impact and effort, and a roadmap that helps you decide whether to address things in phases or take a bigger leap. And did we mention it’s free?

Get in touch

title: Payments infrastructure: how to get it right
author: marceloferreira
content:
Modern payments infrastructure powers smooth, secure transactions. Learn how to choose the right setup for your business.

Payments infrastructure can be easily overlooked, until a payment fails, a settlement delays, or a platform can’t scale fast enough. And when that happens, it’s more than just annoying. It affects cash flow, customer trust, and team sanity.

If you’re building digital products, running a marketplace, managing subscriptions, or just trying to modernize your finance stack, it’s worth getting this part right. Let’s break down what that means.

What is payments infrastructure, really?

Simply put, payments infrastructure is the system behind how your business moves money: in, out, across platforms, countries, accounts, and regulatory hurdles. It’s the tech that lets you accept a payment, route it properly, keep it secure, and make sure it shows up where it’s supposed to.

This includes everything from payment gateways and processors to APIs,

compliance tools

, fraud detection, reconciliation engines, and

reporting dashboards

. It connects the front-end experience your users see with the back-end controls your finance and ops teams rely on. When it’s done right, no one talks about it, because it just works. When it’s not? Well, everyone’s starts to worry about what’s going on.

So yes, it’s technical. But it’s also strategic. And if you’re building, scaling, or even just trying to get your payments to behave, this is a layer you can’t afford to ignore.

How payments infrastructure really works

Payments infrastructure makes sure every transaction moves securely, accurately, and fast from end to end. And that takes a lot of coordination behind the scenes.

At its core, the process connects three main players: the

payer

(your customer), the

payee

(your company), and a

payment intermediary

(like Stripe or a custom gateway). The transaction flows from the customer’s input through the gateway to the payment processor. It then gets verified by the issuing bank and lands in your merchant account.

To make this happen, three key steps take place:

Authorization

: Verifies the customer’s info and approves (or denies) the transaction.

Clearing

: Confirms and processes the details, applying any necessary fees.

Settlement

: Actually moves the funds into your account.

Supporting this flow are critical components:

Gateways

, which encrypt and transmit data securely.

Processors

, which handle communication across banks and networks.

Merchant accounts

, which temporarily hold funds before final deposit.

Banks and networks

(Visa, Mastercard, etc.), which make the connections and charge fees in the background.

Why solid payments infrastructure matters

Payments infrastructure may not be the flashiest part of your stack, but when it’s strong, things just move. And when it’s not, your customers start losing patience. Here’s what a proper setup gets you.

Effortless speed

No one wants to wait for payments to clear. Not your customers, not your CFO. A solid infrastructure reduces lag, errors, and awkward “where’s my money?” emails.

Reconciliation that doesn’t sweep up days

If you’re still matching transactions manually or switching between dashboards, good infrastructure can give you back hours. Or days.

Fewer fires, less risk

From fraud detection to compliance checks, modern payments tools bake in security from the start. That means fewer surprises and late-night fixes.

Room to grow

Expanding into new markets? Adding new revenue streams? A flexible setup means you can scale without duct-taping tools together every time something changes.

A better experience, front to back

Smooth checkout for users, cleaner reporting for finance, less hassle for everyone. It adds up, even if you’re not always noticing it.

Off-the-shelf vs custom-built: which payments infrastructure is right for you?

When it comes to payments infrastructure, one of the biggest decisions you’ll face early on is this:

should you go with a ready-made platform or

build something custom

? Here’s how to approach the decision smartly.

Off-the-shelf solutions: fast, but not always flexible

Pre-built platforms like Salesforce, Stripe, Adyen, or PayPal are powerful, well-documented, and can get you live fast. If your business model is straightforward (say, standard e-commerce or

SaaS

), these tools cover most bases out of the box.

They’re great for:

Fast go-to-market.

Low initial complexity.

Access to proven features like fraud protection, local payment methods, and compliance handling.

However, keep in mind that off-the-shelf tools weren’t made for

you

. The more unique your flows, pricing logic, user types, or markets, the more you’ll bump into limitations. Custom logic often requires fragile workarounds. And you might end up paying for features you don’t need or building on top of a tool that wasn’t designed for your model.

Custom infrastructure: built to fit, built to scale

When your payment flows are complex, your product is non-standard, or you need

deep integrations across systems

, a custom setup can give you real leverage. You can design it to reflect your exact logic and automate the right steps.

Custom is ideal when you:

Need more control over user experience and flow.

Have unique business logic or marketplace architecture.

Want clean integrations with internal systems like ERP,

CRM

, or billing.

See infrastructure as a strategic differentiator, not just a utility.

It may take more time upfront, but the payoff is worth considering: less friction,

better automation

, and infrastructure that grows with your business instead of getting in the way.

The smart middle ground: hybrid approaches

Sometimes the answer isn’t “either/or.” You can use solid off-the-shelf tools as a foundation and layer custom logic where it matters most, through APIs, middleware, or automation flows.

This hybrid approach gives you the speed of plug-and-play and the flexibility of tailored design. And it’s where

Near Partner

often steps in: designing automation layers, reconciliation logic, or integration bridges that transform a generic setup into a perfect-fit solution, without reinventing the wheel.

We can also help you evaluate where you stand, identify where customization creates value, and build what’s missing (without overengineering the rest).

How to get started with the right payments infrastructure

Picking the right payments infrastructure starts with asking better questions and avoiding quick fixes that become long-term regrets. Here’s how to approach it the smart way.

1. Map your payment ecosystem properly

Before you even compare platforms or vendors, take the time to map out how money flows through your business. Are you processing one-off payments, subscriptions, marketplace payouts, usage-based billing? Are you receiving funds globally? Splitting revenue between partners? Handling refunds or chargebacks? Document all of it, and not just the ideal path, but the edge cases too.

2. Prioritize flexibility and extensibility

Choose a setup that won’t lock you in. That means APIs that are clear and well-documented, platforms that integrate easily with your stack, and providers that don’t make you beg for feature updates.

Look for modularity

. That means systems that let you swap parts in or out as your needs evolve. Bonus points for providers with good dev support and real roadmaps.

3. Think globally, even if you’re not there yet

If you plan to expand (or even if international customers find you first) you’ll want infrastructure that supports local payment methods, currency conversion, and regulatory compliance in different regions.

A setup that works beautifully for 100 transactions a month might crumble at 10,000 if it wasn’t built to scale. However, that doesn’t mean you need to go all-in from day one. But choosing infrastructure that’s built for global scale will save you from painful migrations down the line.

4. Don’t sleep on reconciliation and reporting

It’s tempting to focus only on customer-facing tools, like fast checkout, sleek interfaces, etc. But don’t forget what happens after the payment is made. How is the

data tracked

? How easy is it to reconcile payments with your accounting systems? What kind of visibility will your finance team have?

Ask about reconciliation tools, export formats, custom reporting, and how easy it is to integrate with your ERP or analytics platform. A lot of platforms fall short here or charge extra for the basics.

5. Consider security, compliance, and support

PCI compliance, anti-fraud measures, transaction monitoring, GDPR… all of it matters. A strong provider should cover most of this by default, but don’t assume. Ask what’s automated, what you’re responsible for, and what happens when something breaks.

And don’t underestimate the value of good support. Will you be stuck in a ticket queue? Or do you get real engineers who understand your use case? That support layer becomes critical when money’s not moving, and you need answers fast.

6. Think beyond payments: think integrations

Your payments system has to talk to the rest of your business. Make sure it connects (cleanly!) with the systems your business already uses.

Finance systems (for reconciliation and reporting)

CRMs (for customer-level insights)

Billing platforms (for dunning, invoicing, etc.)

Dashboards and alerting (for real-time ops visibility)

The more these connections are automated and stable, the less fire-fighting your team will have to do. And yes,

Near Partner

can help you build those bridges, fast and clean.

7. Roll out in phases and stay lean

Instead of launching everything at once, go live with a stable core first: secure, compliant, and reliable payment processing. Then iterate from there. Add reporting, reconciliation tools, dashboards, alerts and automations in smart phases, based on real needs. Measure how things are working before investing in extra complexity.

8. Run a pilot, always

Before you commit, test. Run a pilot with your real flows, real customers, and real edge cases. This is where all the marketing promises get stress-tested. See how long integration takes, how intuitive the dashboard is, how fast support responds, and how your finance team handles the data.

A provider that can’t handle your complexity at a small scale definitely won’t manage it at full speed.

9, Monitor, iterate, improve

Once you’re live, the work isn’t over. Track what’s working. Keep an eye on errors, drop-offs, latency, and edge cases. Look at your support tickets. Listen to users.

And then tweak. Iterate. Optimize. That’s how you turn infrastructure into advantage.

What’s next for payments infrastructure?

The competition is heating up between banks, fintechs, and big tech, and innovation is being driven by both customer expectations and emerging technologies. Here’s what’s on the horizon (and already knocking at your door):

Omnichannel is non-negotiable

: Online, in-store, mobile: the line is gone. Payments need to flow seamlessly across all channels.

Digital wallets are booming

: Apple Pay, Google Pay and others are dominating checkout screens. Support them, or risk being left behind.

Biometrics are the new password

: Face, fingerprint, voice: expect security and speed in one move.

AI is doing the heavy lifting

: From fraud prevention to smarter risk management and personalized payment experiences.

Real-time payments

are becoming the standard. Instant, frictionless, and great for both your customers and your cash flow.

Crypto and IoT

aren’t mainstream (yet), but they’re gaining ground. If your market or customers lean that way, stay prepared.

Need a partner that knows payments infrastructure inside and out?

At

Near Partner

, we help teams go from “we need something better” to “we’ve got this sorted.” We help you:

Understand what kind of payments infrastructure you need.

Design custom integrations that work with your stack.

Implement automation that’s reliable, maintainable, and scalable.

We handle the full implementation with your team, to make sure your payments setup is efficient, scalable, and built to last.

Get in touch

and let’s build the right way. Ready when you are.

title: Revenue Lifecycle Management Software: how to pick the right one
author: Bárbara Basílio
content:
Revenue Lifecycle Management software can simplify sales and boost recurring revenue. Here’s how to choose the right one for your business.

Quoting takes too long. Pricing feels inconsistent. Invoices get delayed, renewals slip through the cracks, and finance spends hours

reconciling revenue

manually.

If any of that sounds familiar, you’re not alone. As more businesses move to recurring revenue models and complex service offerings, the traditional sales-to-cash process starts to break.

That’s where Revenue Lifecycle Management software stands out. In this guide, we’ll walk through what it does and how it simplifies complexity and unlocks more predictable growth.

What is Revenue Lifecycle Management Software

Revenue Lifecycle Management software helps businesses manage every stage of the revenue process, from the first quote to renewals, in one connected system.

That includes:

Product and pricing setup

Quoting and contracting

Order management and billing

Revenue recognition and compliance

Renewals and upselling

Instead of relying on spreadsheets, emails, and disconnected tools, RLM brings structure and visibility to the entire revenue cycle. You can see where deals stand, track revenue more accurately, and respond faster to changes.

Source:

salesforce

It’s especially valuable for companies with recurring revenue, complex product catalogues, or strict

compliance requirements

. Think healthcare, telecom, or software-as-a-service.

Why Revenue Lifecycle Software matters

The real benefit of Revenue Lifecycle Management Software? It brings structure to a part of your business that often runs on fragmented tools, ad hoc approvals, and back-and-forth emails. Here’s what the right system can do:

Bring clarity to pricing and product offerings

No more hunting for the latest price list or wondering which discount rules apply. Everything’s in one place, version-controlled and accessible.

Fonte:

Salesforce

Speed up quote-to-cash

Automate approvals, generate contracts in seconds, and eliminate the lag between a verbal “yes” and a signed deal.

Reduce revenue leakage

Small inconsistencies in pricing, billing delays, and manual errors add up, and fast. A good system keeps things consistent, traceable, and auditable.

Align sales, finance and legal

These teams don’t always speak the same language, but when they work from the same source of truth, alignment becomes much easier.

Support complex models

Whether it’s subscriptions, usage-based pricing, multi-year contracts or bundles, it handles the logic, so your team doesn’t have to.

The limits of Revenue Lifecycle Software

What could possibly go wrong? Well, as powerful as Revenue Lifecycle Management software can be, it’s not always the silver bullet people hope for. Here’s where things can get tricky:

1. You can’t automate what you don’t understand

Throwing software at a messy process won’t fix it. It just makes the mess more visible. If your quoting, pricing, or billing logic isn’t clear, no tool will solve that for you. The system needs structured inputs.

2. Customization creep is real

It’s tempting to tweak everything to match how your team

currently

works. But over-customizing often leads to bloated systems that are hard to maintain or upgrade. You end up boxed in by your own “flexibility”.

3. It still needs people

People still need to validate exceptions, handle edge cases, and adjust pricing strategies. A good system supports your team, and does not replace them.

4. Integration isn’t always plug-and-play

Yes, most tools claim they “integrate seamlessly” with your CRM, ERP or billing systems. But do the reality? Expect some work.

Data cleanup

, mapping, and change management are all part of the journey.

5. It can be expensive if badly scoped

Poorly defined requirements lead to overbuilt systems, delayed implementations and underwhelming results. Without a clear scope and phased approach, your budget can disappear fast.

Buy or build? Choosing between off-the-shelf and custom Revenue Lifecycle Software

When you’re ready to adopt Revenue Lifecycle Management software, one of the first big questions is: should we buy a ready-made solution or build one tailored to our needs? There’s no one-size-fits-all answer, so here’s how to weigh the trade-offs.

Off-the-shelf: fast, proven, but sometimes frustrating

Pre-built solutions like Salesforce CPQ are great when you want to move quickly and adopt established best practices. They’re tested, supported, regularly updated, and often come with built-in integrations.

However, you’ll need to adapt your processes to the tool, not the other way around. And if your business model is even slightly unconventional, you may end up forcing workarounds or battling limitations that slow your team down.

Good fit for:

companies with relatively standard quoting, pricing, and billing flows who want fast deployment and predictable costs.

Built-from-scratch: tailored precision, but higher stakes

Custom-built solutions

give you full control. Every screen, rule, and flow can match your reality. If your pricing models are complex or if you need to integrate with internal systems that off-the-shelf tools don’t handle well, this might be the way to go.

Of course, building from scratch takes time. And discipline. Without a clear scope and experienced team, it’s easy to end up reinventing features that commercial tools already nailed.

Good fit for:

companies with unique processes or highly specific regulatory/compliance needs, and with the bandwidth to support a proper development cycle.

How to get started

Revenue Lifecycle Management sounds complex and, let’s be honest, it can be. But the trick is to focus on impact and not just features. Here’s how to do that in practice:

1. Map your revenue flow

Start by breaking down your existing revenue journey:

Where does a deal start?

What steps does it go through (quote, approval, invoicing, renewal)?

Where are things slow, manual, or error-prone?

Even a rough sketch on paper is a powerful first step. This clarity helps you focus your effort where it’ll count.

2. Prioritise pain points

You don’t need to fix everything at once. Choose one or two high-impact problems to solve first.  Look for:

Bottlenecks that slow down deals

Gaps where revenue is lost (e.g., missed renewals, inconsistent pricing)

Compliance risks or reporting headaches

3. Audit your existing tools

Before adding more tools to the mix, take stock of what’s already in play. You might have a

CRM here

, an ERP there, a quoting tool no one really loves, and yet they’re all part of the same revenue puzzle.

Look at how these systems talk to each other (or don’t), where data gets stuck, and what processes are still painfully manual. This is a chance to find hidden efficiencies, spot what’s dragging you down, and make sure you’re not paying for things that don’t deliver.

4. Define what “better” looks like

Go beyond features. Define what a better process should feel like:

Faster quote-to-cash?

Fewer manual approvals?

Real-time visibility into revenue projections?

5. Get the right voices in the room

Don’t wait until you’re knee-deep in implementation to ask sales, finance or ops what’s broken. They’re the ones who hit roadblocks every day: the approval delays, the pricing inconsistencies, the double data entry.

Bringing them in from the start it’s how you avoid building something polished that solves the wrong problems. Plus, involving the right people early tends to make adoption much smoother later.

6. Start small, but aim wide

You don’t need to rebuild your entire revenue process overnight. The smartest approach? Pick one area where the pain is sharp and the impact will be felt fast. But whatever you roll out, make sure it’s designed to scale. That means

integrations

won’t be a nightmare, user roles won’t get messy, and you’re not setting yourself up for a second rebuild in a year.

Why Salesforce CPQ might be your shortcut to RLM done right

You won’t have to chase legal every time you need the latest template. Manual copy-paste mistakes become a thing of the past. And complex deals flow smoothly without holdups.

Here’s what makes Salesforce CPQ a strong foundation for Revenue Lifecycle Management:

Approval workflows, renewals, upsell triggers, contract generation – they all happen in the background, reducing admin and human error.

title: Vibe coding: what is it and is it right for your company?
author: Bárbara Basílio
content:
Everyone’s trying vibe coding, but is it really that simple? Find out what it is, its pros and cons, and how to do it right.

You had an idea, typed it into an AI assistant, and minutes later you had working code. No devs, no delays, no meetings. Just results.

At least, that’s what it looked like, until things stopped working. Or worse, something broke and you didn’t know how to fix it. That’s the promise and the danger of vibe coding: it gives you just enough to get started, but not enough to do it right.

In this article, we’re unpacking the vibe coding trend: what it is, why it’s growing, and why going solo with AI tools isn’t always the smart move. Especially when performance, security, or long-term reliability matter.

What is vibe coding?

Vibe coding is what happens when non-developers use AI tools like Cursor, Windsurf or

GitHub Copilot

to write code based on natural

language prompts

– often without understanding how that code actually works.

It feels empowering. You describe what you want, the AI gives you code, and you see it running within minutes. But beneath the surface, there’s often a fragile setup held together by guesses, assumptions, and untested logic.

Benefits of vibe coding

There’s a reason vibe coding is popping up in hackathons, pitch decks and Slack channels: it feels like the future. AI tools are closing the gap between intention and execution, and for anyone who’s ever had an idea but didn’t know how to code, it seems magical.

It feels fast

One prompt in, working code out. That sense of instant progress is incredibly rewarding. Need a form? A database? An API call? You ask, and the AI delivers, skipping planning, research, or even design. When you’re exploring ideas, this speed is energising.

It’s cheap

Hiring developers takes time and budget. Vibe coding seems to remove both barriers. Why spend on a prototype when you can piece it together yourself over a weekend with free tools?

It feels accessible

Anyone can write “build me a form that sends data to a spreadsheet”, and get something that

kind of

works. That’s a big deal for marketers, founders, product leads, even interns. It gives people a way to get involved. But it also blurs the line between usable and reliable, between “it runs” and “it’s robust”.

It hides the complexity

Vibe coding gives you the output, not the understanding. There’s no learning curve, no documentation, no architecture decisions. That’s the point… and the problem. You get working pieces, but no structure. No separation of concerns. No safety nets.

Limitations of vibe coding

Beneath the surface, a dangerous reality may be taking shape: fragile code, without technical criteria, or minimum guarantees of security, performance or maintainability. Here’s where things get threatening.

Security is almost always an afterthought

Code generated by AI tools often lacks even the most basic security best practices. No input validation. No protection against common vulnerabilities like XSS, SQL injection or CSRF. And because the person using the tool may not know what to check for, these risks can go completely unnoticed, until there’s a breach.

Performance bottlenecks show up late

When you’re testing alone or with a handful of users, almost anything seems fast enough. But once your product hits real traffic, inefficient logic, unoptimized queries or poorly structured DOM manipulation can create massive slowdowns. And because the code wasn’t designed with scale in mind, there’s often no easy fix.

Fragile architecture

Vibe coding tends to generate isolated bits of code (components that work in the moment, but aren’t part of any overarching system). There’s no codebase cohesion. No version control. No documentation. When it breaks (and it will), there’s no structure to fall back on, and often no clear path to fix it.

Invisible tech debt

The cost of technical decisions doesn’t show up on day one. It creeps in: when adding new features becomes harder than expected, when bugs are unpredictable, or when your team can’t understand the code well enough to improve it. That “quick solution” now comes with months of headaches.

Compliance risks

Especially in industries like

healthcare

,

finance

or education, software has to comply with strict data, accessibility, or auditability standards. Vibe coding doesn’t account for any of this. And without a proper development partner, you might not even realise you’re non-compliant.

How to use vibe coding

Used carefully, vibe coding can be a helpful tool, but it’s not plug-and-play magic. If you’re going to explore it, treat it like a sharp object: it can do great things, but only if you handle it with care.

Use it to explore ideas

If you’re still sketching out a product or testing whether something makes sense, vibe coding can be incredibly useful. You can ask for a quick landing page, a demo form, or a mock interface.

Say you want to test how users react to a new booking flow. Instead of waiting for a dev sprint, you generate a working prototype with vibe coding, get feedback, then hand over real requirements to your development team.

Always test it yourself, properly

AI-generated code often “looks” right, but can break in quiet, dangerous ways. Don’t just click the button once and assume it works. Try wrong inputs. Try edge cases. Try breaking it. Use dev tools (browser console, network tab) and validation checkers (like WAVE for accessibility or Lighthouse for performance) to really see what’s going on under the hood.

Ask someone technical to review it

Even if you’re not planning to release it publicly, don’t skip peer review. AI-generated code can hide performance issues, insecure patterns (like unsanitised inputs), or practices that will make maintenance harder later.

Share your generated code with a developer you trust. Ask: “Would this hold up in production?” Their reaction will tell you a lot.

Use it as a way to learn, not shortcut

Instead of just copying and pasting, try asking follow-up questions: why did it use this method? What could go wrong with this approach?

The more you learn, the less you’ll rely on luck, and the better decisions you’ll make when things get complicated.

Is vibe coding right for you?

Before jumping in, ask yourself: is this the right tool for the job, or just the most tempting?

It might be the right fit if…

You’re working solo on a small idea or internal tool

You need a quick prototype to present or validate

You’re building something low-risk (no user data, no payments, no logins)

You understand that you’ll need to rewrite the code later

Probably not a good match if…

You’re working in a regulated industry

You want to scale the code, integrate APIs, or maintain it long-term

You can’t risk downtime, security breaches, or poor performance

Alternatives to vibe coding

Not all fast development means risky shortcuts. There are powerful platforms and methods that let you move quickly without compromising structure or quality.

Low-code platforms

Tools like

OutSystems

let you build applications visually, connecting logic and UI with drag-and-drop flows, while still generating enterprise-grade code underneath.

Good for:

Internal business tools

Customer portals

Apps that need integrations but not full custom code

Benefits:

Pre-built components (no need to reinvent buttons or forms)

Built-in security, validation and deployment flows

Easier to scale and maintain than vibe-coded snippets

However, you’ll still need dev guidance, especially when the logic becomes complex or when performance matters.

Salesforce Lightning Platform

If your project revolves around customer data, sales, support, or CRM logic, Salesforce’s Lightning Platform can be a smart choice. It’s powerful, battle-tested, and deeply integrated into enterprise ecosystems.

Good for:

Automating business processes

Building customer-facing portals connected to your CRM

Extending sales or service workflows

Benefits:

Rich ecosystem of apps and integrations

Advanced reporting, workflows, and automations

Enterprise-grade compliance and support

Custom dev with Near Partner

Sometimes your idea doesn’t fit into templates or flows. It needs to be

built with intention

. That’s where we come in.

At Near Partner, we help define what should be built, and how to do it right. You get a project that’s clear, documented, scalable, and ready for real users, and not just a pretty prototype.

Good for:

Full product development

Critical business systems

Anything with sensitive data or real usage expectations

Benefits:

Architecture, scalability, and performance from day one

Clear communication and human partnership

Real development with real accountability

Build smarter and find your vibe with us

There’s a lot of excitement around AI-powered development. And it makes sense. The tools are impressive, the process feels intuitive, and it lowers the barrier to experimentation. But turning that experiment into something real, something that lasts, takes more than a prompt. It takes judgement. Experience. Criteria.

At

Near Partner

, we design solutions with purpose. That means thinking about architecture before jumping into syntax. It means validating security, optimising performance, and making sure your product is reliable, scalable, and understandable – for you, your team, and the people who use it.

We’re not here to replace your ideas with rigid processes. We help you to build properly from the start, with the right structure, the right safeguards, and a team that’s thinking several steps ahead.

Because when it comes to code that powers real businesses, “it runs” isn’t the finish line. It’s where we begin.

title: System integration: a step-by-step practical guide (with AI)
author: Sérgio
content:
System integration offers huge gains, but many projects still fail. See how to unlock real ROI, carefully and with strategy.

In October 2022, just ahead of the all-important Christmas spending season,

multinational retailer Spar unveiled their flagship SAP project

. Touted as a landmark transformation, the system was meant to position the company for a decade of growth and revolutionize its relationship with distributors. Instead, it became a cautionary tale in system integration.

Problems surfaced almost immediately. Severe supply chain disruptions rippled across the business. Independent Spar retailers in KwaZulu-Natal (KZN), who had long relied on centralized operations, suddenly had to source stock directly from manufacturers or alternative suppliers. To contain the crisis, Spar diverted inventory from warehouses in other provinces—an expensive and inefficient stopgap.

By September 2023, the consequences were staggering: an estimated 100 million in lost turnover. Recovery would take years of painstaking manual intervention.

Spar’s missteps are hardly unique. Large-scale system integrations can radically reshape how companies operate, but they almost never succeed with the flick of a switch. In fact,

only one in three digital transformation initiatives

ever meet their intended goals.

The culprit is often not the technology itself, but the lack of planning, alignment, cultural readiness, and change management. And if global giants like Spar can stumble, what chance do smaller organizations have when embarking on a digital integration journey?

The good news: success is possible. There are practical strategies you can adopt—and classic pitfalls you can avoid. Here are some of the most important ones.

What do we mean by system integration?

At its core,

system integration

is about making different software and platforms work together as one. Instead of having your

CRM

, ERP, HR system, and

cloud apps

operating in isolation (each with its own data and workflows), integration connects them into a single, unified ecosystem.

That means customer data flows seamlessly from sales to finance,

supply chain

updates are visible in real time, and reporting no longer requires endless copy-paste marathons. In other words, system integration eliminates silos and replaces them with a connected backbone where information moves freely, accurately, and securely across the business.

The benefits of system integration that companies actually feel

System integration often gets framed as a “tech upgrade,” but the real story is much bigger. The impact shows up in day-to-day operations, employee productivity, customer experience and, ultimately, the bottom line. Here’s what businesses stand to gain.

1. Efficiency without the busywork

No more

duplicate data

entry or switching between five different platforms to complete a single task. When systems talk to each other, workflows become seamless, freeing teams from the manual work that eats away hours every week. It’s like finally removing the sand from the gears. Everything just moves faster.

2. Data that flows (and tells the truth)

One of the biggest headaches for growing companies is scattered, inconsistent data. Integration creates a single source of truth, ensuring finance, sales, operations, and HR are all looking at the same numbers. Decisions become sharper because they’re based on real-time, reliable information rather than gut instinct or outdated spreadsheets.

3. Smarter (and faster) decisions

Executives no longer need to wait for “end-of-month reports” to know what’s happening. With connected systems,

data dashboards

update in real time. That means spotting risks earlier, reacting to market shifts quicker, and seizing opportunities before competitors do.

4. Better customer experience

When your CRM, billing, and support platforms work in harmony, customers notice. Faster responses, fewer errors, personalized interactions – it all adds up to stronger trust and loyalty. In fact, research shows that companies with connected data

outperform competitors

in customer satisfaction and retention.

5. Easier scalability

Growth usually means adding more tools, people, and processes. Without integration, that can spiral into digital anarchy. But with a connected backbone, scaling feels less like firefighting and more like building on solid ground. New systems plug in smoothly, data keeps flowing, and teams don’t drown in complexity.

The limitations of system integration you can’t afford to ignore

System integration comes with its own set of challenges that companies need to plan for. Being aware of these limitations is the first step to overcoming them.

1. Compatibility issues between systems

Not all platforms play nicely together. Legacy systems, outdated software, or heavily customized tools can make integration tricky. Sometimes it means extra middleware, custom development, or even retiring older systems altogether.

2. Security and compliance risks

Every connection between systems is also a potential vulnerability. If integration isn’t handled with proper safeguards, it can expose sensitive data to breaches or compliance issues, especially in sectors like

finance

or

healthcare

where regulations are strict.

3. Change management hurdles

The tech may be ready, but people aren’t always on board. Employees used to manual workflows or siloed systems may resist change, making training and communication critical to a smooth rollout. No doubt that integration connects software, but it also should bring people along too.

4. Maintenance and continuous updates

Once systems are integrated, they don’t stay static. Updates, new platforms, and changing business needs mean integrations must be maintained and adapted over time. Without ongoing support, even the best integration can become outdated or fragile.

AI in system integration

With AI stepping in, the mechanics of system integration look very different than they did a few years ago. Intelligent agents can now act as the “connective tissue” between platforms, automating data flows, monitoring system health, and even making decisions in real time. Instead of relying only on traditional APIs or manual intervention, companies are experimenting with AI-driven orchestration to speed up processes and unlock new efficiencies.

The benefits are clear: faster integrations, reduced human error, and the ability to scale connections across increasingly complex environments. An AI agent can, for example, detect when data looks inconsistent between systems, correct it on the fly, and prevent downstream errors. It can also learn patterns over time, predicting when bottlenecks or failures might occur, which is something static integration models can’t do.

AI-driven integration also brings risks: opaque decision-making, over-reliance on algorithms that might misinterpret context, and regulatory or compliance challenges when sensitive data is involved. A misconfigured or poorly trained agent can spread errors faster than a human ever could.

In short, AI opens a powerful new chapter for system integration, but one that requires caution, governance, and a clear understanding of its limitations. The companies that thrive will be those that balance automation with oversight, ensuring technology augments human judgment rather than replacing it.

System Integration implementation: a step-by-step guide

Here’s a practical roadmap to get system integration right.

1. Map your business processes, not just systems

Before you touch any software, map the

workflows

and business processes that span multiple systems. Identify dependencies, bottlenecks, and pain points. Integration succeeds when it reflects real business activity, not just IT architecture.

2. Audit data quality and consistency

Integration is only as good as the data flowing through it. Identify inconsistencies, duplicates, or gaps across systems before building connections. Dirty data leads to automated mess, instead of streamlined operations.

3. Define clear integration objectives

Know what “success” looks like. Are you aiming for faster reporting, fewer errors, or better

customer experience

? Setting measurable goals ensures ROI is tangible and the project doesn’t drift into a generic IT exercise.

4. Choose the right integration approach

Decide between real-time vs. batch, point-to-point vs. middleware, or API-first approaches depending on complexity and scale. Avoid the trap of copying legacy workflows into automation, because it often amplifies inefficiencies.

5. Design for security and compliance

Every connection introduces

potential vulnerabilities

. Plan security measures, access controls, and audit trails from day one. This protects both the business and customer trust.

6. Pilot, test, and iterate

Start small with a pilot integration. Test for performance, edge cases, and unexpected behaviors. Involve end-users early to catch usability issues. Iterate before full-scale rollout to avoid costly mistakes.

7. Train teams and drive adoption

Even the most elegant integration fails if people don’t use it. Train employees, provide support materials, and incentivize adoption. Highlight how integration simplifies their work, rather than just presenting it as a technical change.

8. Monitor, maintain, and evolve

Continuously monitor performance, update for new tools or business needs, and refine workflows to ensure long-term value.

Low-code solutions for system integration

Connecting systems no longer means months of custom coding. Low-code and no-code platforms have rewritten the rulebook. Instead of relying solely on custom code and large development teams, businesses now have the option to connect tools quickly using visual interfaces, prebuilt connectors, and automation engines. Here’s a closer look at the main players and how they fit into different business needs.

OutSystems

, for exemple, takes things up a level, offering a full low-code development platform that includes integration capabilities. It can build full systems and extend existing infrastructures. Enterprises that need scalability, governance, and complex system integrations. You can build custom applications while still speeding up delivery through low-code.

Salesforce

offers its own suite of integration capabilities, from MuleSoft to native connectors. For organizations already living inside Salesforce, these tools make it possible to unify data across departments and streamline customer journeys.

System integration with Near Partner

System integration has the power to transform the way a company operates and unlock its full potential.

At

Near Partner

, we craft connected ecosystems that reflect how your business actually works. Our team designs integrations that link your CRM, ERP, HR systems, cloud apps, and more, ensuring data flows effortlessly, insights are actionable, and teams can focus on value rather than manual work.

If you’re aiming to cut operational costs, scale quickly, or improve service delivery, our integration solutions are tailored to deliver measurable results. We combine technical expertise with a deep understanding of business processes, guiding you from strategy to execution and beyond.

Ready to see what connected systems can do for your business?

Get in touch with Near Partner

today and discover how smart integration turns data into growth.

title: Field Service Management: what is it and how to do it right
author: Sérgio
content:
is, why it is important and how to do it right with practical insights.

You sent a technician out at 9:00. By 11:00, the client is calling to ask where they are. Your internal tracker says the job’s done. The technician hasn’t even arrived. Somewhere between the scheduling tool, the service app and the chat group, the thread got lost.

This is the kind of everyday chaos that eats away at

efficiency

, client trust and your team’s sanity. And it’s more common than most companies care to admit. Field service management shouldn’t feel like a high-stakes guessing game. So let’s talk about what’s really going wrong — and what to do when your operations keep hitting the same wall.

Field Service Management is the coordination of resources — people, equipment and information — when work needs to be done on-site. Think installations, repairs, maintenance and inspections. It involves scheduling, dispatching, tracking, reporting and everything in between.

What is Field Service Management?

A well-oiled Field Service Management system means less time wasted, more accurate work,

better client experience

and real-time visibility over what’s happening out in the field. However, very few companies actually get it right.

8 signs you need to improve your Field Service Management (and what to do about it)

Below are some of the main sticking points — and how we usually help untangle the mess.

1. Scheduling Is a nightmare: too many jobs, not enough context

Schedulers are trying to match technicians to tasks without the full picture. Skillsets, availability, location, job urgency — none of it is centralised or easy to act on. The result? Overbookings, idle time or wrong person for the job.

What to do:

Invest in a scheduling solution that lets you visualise workloads, technician skills and availability in real time. Avoid static calendars or overcomplicated tools.

2. Your systems don’t talk to each other

You’ve got CRM in one place, job tracking in another, technician notes in a third tool, and Excel patching the gaps. By the time you know something went wrong, it already escalated.

What to do:

map out all the tools currently in use and identify where information is getting lost. Prioritise systems that can be integrated, or replaced, so data flows between them without manual effort.

3. Technicians waste time on admin tasks

Technicians spend too long writing reports, dealing with clunky mobile tools or calling in to confirm basic info. That’s time better spent on actual work — and they know it.

What to do:

Look for mobile tools designed specifically for field work — fast to use, intuitive, and capable of working offline.

4. Clients are always in the dark

Your client expected someone by 10:00. It’s 10:40. They haven’t heard anything. You don’t even know if the technician’s stuck in traffic or forgot the job. It’s a trust issue, and one that costs you repeat business.

What to do:

Set up automated notifications at key stages of the service: appointment confirmed, technician en route, job completed. Transparency doesn’t have to be manual, and clients will notice.

5. Data is collected but never used

You’re collecting a mountain of data: service times, repeat issues, technician efficiency. But no one’s analysing it. Opportunities for improvement are buried in dashboards no one opens.

What to do:

Identify a few key metrics you actually care about, and make them visible. Build regular habits around reviewing them and acting on trends.

6. No standard process across teams

Each technician has their own way of doing things. Some document everything, others don’t bother. One team follows procedure, the other cuts corners. The result? Inconsistency, confusion, and no way to scale quality.

What to do:

Define a standard workflow for the most common job types and make it easy to follow — digitally.

Step-by-step guidance

, checklists and required fields can help build consistency without policing your team.

7. Onboarding new technicians takes forever

When know-how lives in people’s heads, new technicians are stuck shadowing others for weeks. Even after that, they’re unsure about protocols, tools or what’s expected of them in the field.

What to do:

Create a lightweight knowledge base with clear job procedures, quick-reference guides and troubleshooting tips.

Pair it with a simple digital assistant or app

so new joiners can learn on the move.

8. Equipment and inventory go untracked

Parts go missing, tools are misplaced, and no one knows who has what. Some techs stock their vans like warehouses, others show up empty-handed. You lose time, money, and sometimes clients.

What to do:

Implement a basic asset

tracking system

(ideally mobile) where technicians can log what they take and return.

What does a good field service tool look like?

The right solution should solve real problems and take the pressure off both your frontline and back office. So before you choose a platform (or build one), here’s what actually matters.

What does a good field service tool look like?

The right FSM software should solve real problems and take the pressure off both your frontline and back office. In other words, a good field service management (FSM) solution should make field service operations run smoother, keep your mobile workforce productive, and ultimately improve customer satisfaction. So before you choose a platform (or build one), here’s what actually matters.

Real-time scheduling and dispatch

Showing up matters. Showing up fast matters more. And with context. You should be able to assign jobs based on availability, location, skillset, and priority, all in real time. Bonus if the system can reassign on the fly when someone calls in sick or a job runs over. This kind of agility keeps service calls under control and ensures customers aren’t left waiting.

Mobile experience

Your mobile workers are the ones using this tool all day long, so make it work for them. That means offline access, fast check-ins, simple data entry, and straightforward navigation. If they’re spending more time figuring out how to update a job than doing the job, it’s the wrong tool. The best FSM software turns every technician’s phone or tablet into a true command center for their work.

Clear job overviews and live status updates

From “assigned” to “in progress” to “done,” you want to see where each job stands without needing a dozen phone calls. What if a client wants an update? With proper customer management built in, you should have that info at your fingertips, from status to service history, in seconds.

Easy logging of work done, issues found, and customer feedback

Your team should be able to document their work (photos, signatures, notes, time spent) without friction. That data is gold for follow-ups, reporting, and continuous improvement. When linked with customer management features, these logs also ensure you’re not asking customers the same questions twice.

Smart asset and inventory management

Who has what, where is it, and is it working? A solid tool should help you track parts, tools and equipment, so your technicians aren’t showing up unprepared or hoarding gear “just in case.” This also supports preventive maintenance, since you can plan ahead rather than constantly reacting to breakdowns.

Built-in quality control

You can’t be everywhere at once. But your tool can help enforce standards: checklists, required fields, automated alerts when something’s missing or off. It may sound micromanaging, but, in fact, it’s really protecting quality at scale and making sure field service operations don’t slip through the cracks.

Reports and KPIs

You shouldn’t need a data analyst to understand what’s going on. A good tool gives you useful insights: average time per job, repeat visits, technician performance, bottlenecks, so you can fix what’s not working. When connected to your field service management (FSM) platform, these insights can directly highlight where to act to improve customer satisfaction.

Seamless integrations with the tools you already use

Your CRM, billing system, customer service tools – they all need to talk to your field service management FSM platform. No double entries. No manual copy-paste. Just data that flows, giving everyone, from mobile workers to back-office staff, a complete view of the service history and every interaction that matters.

What are the best Salesforce-based solutions for field service?

If your business already

runs on Salesforce

, you don’t have to start from scratch. There are several field service solutions that plug right in, extending what you already use and eliminating most of the integration pain. But each one plays a different role. Here’s a breakdown of the main players, and when it makes sense to choose them.

Salesforce Field Service (FSL)

This is Salesforce’s own native solution, and it covers the end-to-end field service lifecycle: from scheduling and dispatch, to real-time tracking, mobile access, inventory management, and customer communication.

It’s ideal if:

You already use Service Cloud or Sales Cloud.

You want a consistent experience across teams.

Your processes are fairly standard but growing in complexity.

Key benefits:

Native integration with Salesforce CRM.

Drag-and-drop scheduling board.

Real-time updates and smart job matching.

Mobile app with offline support.

Sitetracker

Sitetracker

was built for companies that run dozens, sometimes hundreds of projects at the same time. If you’re in telecom, energy, or infrastructure and need to keep everything on track without losing sight of the details, this platform gives you that clarity. You can count on deployment schedules, resource allocation, real-time reporting, and much more. Sitetracker helps you stay in control, even when things get complex.

It’s ideal if:

You manage lots of concurrent field projects with multiple milestones.

You need consistent reporting and forecasting across teams.

You’re scaling fast and can’t afford operational blind spots.

Key benefits:

Project templates and standardised workflows for repeatability.

Real-time dashboards for progress, risks, and resources.

Mobile tools for field teams with status updates and photo capture.

Seamless integrations with CRMs, ERPs, and inventory systems.

Simplify Workflows

Simplify Workflows is for teams that want to move faster and with less friction. Instead of waiting weeks for custom solutions or juggling spreadsheets, you can turn your field processes into automated workflows in just a few clicks. It’s flexible, intuitive, and designed for people who know the process, not necessarily how to code it.

It’s ideal if:

You want to digitise manual workflows without custom builds.

Your team needs automation that’s easy to set up and adjust.

You want to empower non-technical users to optimise processes.

Key benefits:

Intuitive drag-and-drop builder for process automation.

Smart forms, notifications, and dynamic task assignment.

Real-time visibility into workflow status and performance.

Flexible integrations with tools you already use.

Field Service Management tools: build or buy?

It’s the big question that comes after identifying your needs: do you buy an existing platform, or build something tailored to your operations? There’s no universal answer. But there are clear scenarios where one approach makes more sense than the other.

Here’s how to weigh the decision.

When to buy off the shelf

Buying a ready-made solution is usually faster, safer, and more predictable. Most tools (like Salesforce Field Service or ServiceMax) already cover 80–90% of what typical businesses need. And if you’re already working with Salesforce, the integration can be nearly seamless.

Choose this path if:

Your business model isn’t wildly unusual.

You want speed and lower upfront costs.

Your internal tech team is small or focused elsewhere.

You’d rather adapt slightly than reinvent everything.

The trade-off? You may have to compromise on some edge cases, or pay for features you won’t fully use. But if speed, stability, and vendor support matter most, you’ll win more than you’ll lose.

When it makes sense to build your own

Sometimes, your operation is simply too specific for a generic solution to fit well. Maybe your workflows are niche, your service areas are complex, or your internal processes are highly regulated. In those cases,

building something tailored

— perhaps with a

low-code platform like OutSystems

— can bring massive advantages.

Choose this path if:

Off-the-shelf tools feel too rigid or bloated.

You need full control over every process, screen and field.

You have internal capabilities (or a trusted partner) to maintain the platform.

You want to innovate or differentiate through the way you deliver service.

Where’s the compromise? Time, budget and maintenance. Custom builds require clear ownership, ongoing updates, and a higher tolerance for iteration. But if you get it right, the tool becomes a real competitive asset.

Not sure yet? Consider a hybrid

You don’t always have to choose one or the other. Some companies start with an off-the-shelf tool and

customise around the edges

using low-code extensions. Others prototype in-house, then migrate to a mature platform once needs are stable.

The key is to stay close to what your teams and clients actually need, and make sure your choice doesn’t become a blocker six months down the line.

Ready to make Field Service Management work like it should?

If your Field Service Management feels more reactive than strategic, it’s probably not the team — it’s the system. With the right setup, things start to click: teams know where to go, clients stay informed, and data actually works for you.

At

Near Partner

, we design and build the custom platforms that make all of this possible. Sharp, scalable solutions that fit your business, and a smarter way to manage work in the real world.

Want to talk through where your current setup might be holding you back?
