title: What is financial reconciliation and how to make it effortlessly?
author: marceloferreira
content:
Discover what financial reconciliation is, how it can help your business and how to do it right.

Every year, businesses

lose an average of $145,000 to poor financial reconciliation

. That’s average – when reconciliation is manual, delayed, or incomplete, those gaps grow wider. But done right, financial reconciliation helps you catch errors early, close control gaps, and keep your business secure. Discover what it is, and to make it right and how automation can protect you.

Discover what financial reconciliation is, how it can help your business and how to do it right.

What is financial reconciliation?

Put simply, financial reconciliation is the accounting term for verifying that financial records from different sources match. It involves comparing internal accounting data — like general ledgers or transaction reports — with external documents, such as

bank statements

, vendor records, or payment processor logs. Any discrepancies that arise during this comparison are flagged, investigated, and corrected to ensure the integrity of financial reporting.

This process is critical for maintaining transparency, preventing errors, and

ensuring compliance

. Reconciliation helps teams stay confident that the numbers they’re working with are reliable. It’s not just about catching mistakes — though that’s important — but about building a solid foundation for smarter decisions, audits, and strategic planning.

Why financial reconciliation matters

The main benefit of a strong financial reconciliation is, obviously, not losing unclaimed money to either vendors or customers. But there are other important benefits you gain by making financial reconciliation a consistent habit.

1. Accurate financial data

Regular reconciliation ensures that your financial data is consistent and error-free. By identifying mismatches early, you reduce the risk of misstatements in your reports, avoid costly mistakes, and keep your numbers aligned with reality.

2. Stronger internal controls

Reconciliation acts as a checkpoint against fraud, duplicate or missing payments, or unauthorized transactions. It adds an extra layer of oversight, making it easier to detect irregularities and reinforcing accountability across financial operations.

3. Smoother audits

When your records are consistently reconciled, audits become far less stressful. Everything is in order, easier to trace, and quicker to validate. That means less scrambling and fewer questions.

4. Informed decision-making

Clean and up-to-date financials lead to better strategic decisions. Reconciliation gives leadership teams the confidence to plan, invest, and grow based on data they trust, without second-guessing what’s real and what’s a reporting error.

5. Enhanced cash flow visibility

By reconciling your books with real-world transactions, you get a clearer picture of where your money is, where it’s going, and how it’s being used. This visibility helps with forecasting, budgeting, and staying agile in changing conditions.

The main types of financial reconciliation

There are different types of financial reconciliation that serve different purposes, depending on the data you’re working with and the outcomes you need.

1. Bank reconciliation

This is the most common type. It involves comparing a company’s internal cash records with bank statements to ensure all deposits, withdrawals, and balances match. It helps spot missed transactions, bank fees, or fraudulent activity.

2. Customer reconciliation

Focused on accounts receivable, this process compares a company’s records of customer invoices and payments with the balances reported by the customer. It’s essential for maintaining clean ledgers and resolving payment disputes quickly.

3. Vendor reconciliation

Also known as supplier reconciliation, this compares the company’s accounts payable records with vendor statements. It ensures that all received goods and services have been accurately recorded and paid for, without duplicates or surprises.

4. Intercompany reconciliation

Used by businesses with multiple entities or subsidiaries, this process ensures that transactions between those entities are correctly recorded on both sides. It’s vital for consolidating financials and avoiding discrepancies within the group.

5. Credit card reconciliation

This matches internal expense records with credit card statements. It helps verify that all charges are valid, properly categorized, and aligned with company policies — which is especially useful for managing employee or business credit cards.

6. Balance sheet reconciliation

A broader process that reviews and validates the balances of key accounts — like assets, liabilities, and equity — at the end of a reporting period. It ensures the financial statements are complete and accurately reflect the company’s position.

How to get financial reconciliation right

With the right structure and tools in place, reconciliation can become a smooth part of your finance routine.

1. Define a clear process

Start with a structured approach. Set steps, assign responsibilities, and make sure everyone follows the same routine. A consistent process helps reduce mistakes and makes the work easier to manage across teams.

2. Reconcile frequently

Don’t wait until the end of the month to start reviewing your records. The more often you reconcile, the easier it is to catch and correct issues. This keeps your data more accurate and saves time in the long run.

3. Organize your documentation

Keep your financial records — like invoices, bank statements, and receipts — well-organized and easy to access. Good documentation speeds up the reconciliation process and supports transparency during internal checks or audits.

4. Use automation and trusted technology partners

Manual work takes time and increases the risk of errors. Automating parts of your reconciliation process helps reduce those risks and frees up your team to focus on more valuable tasks. At

Near Partner

, we build custom solutions that adapt to your workflows, helping you automate what makes sense and simplify the rest. We’re here to support your finance team with the right tech.

5. Review and improve regularly

Even a good process can be improved. Make time to review your reconciliation workflow, gather input from your team, and adjust where needed. Continuous improvements lead to better results and fewer issues over time.

The power of automation in financial reconciliation

Automation fundamentally changes how reconciliation gets done, making it more reliable, scalable, and insightful. Here’s how automation steps in to handle the heavy lifting and make your finance operations smarter every day.

Seamless data integration

Automation connects multiple financial systems — bank feeds, accounting software, payment gateways — pulling data together in real time. This removes the need for manual data entry and ensures you’re working with the freshest information, without delays or mismatches.

Smart transaction matching

Automated systems use configurable rules to handle exceptions and partial matches. They can recognize patterns like recurring payments or split transactions, reducing false mismatches and minimizing manual reviews.

Dynamic exception handling

When transactions don’t match, automation doesn’t just flag the problem — it prioritizes issues based on risk or value, suggests possible reasons, and even recommends next steps. This turns reconciliation from a reactive chore into a proactive process.

Automated documentation and audit trails

Every matched or flagged transaction is logged with full traceability, and supporting documents are automatically linked and stored. This built-in audit trail saves time during reviews and builds trust in your financial data integrity.

Make financial reconciliation smarter with Near Partner

Reconciliation doesn’t have to be a drain on your team’s time or energy. With the right tools in place, it becomes faster, more accurate, and way easier to manage.

At

Near Partner

, we take the time to understand how your processes work, and we build smart, flexible automation around them. If you need better integrations, custom dashboards, or a fully automated reconciliation flow, we’re here to make it all work — the way it should.

Let’s talk

. We’d love to hear how you work — and help you build a smarter to do it.

title: Building scalable solutions: 7 key pitfalls to avoid
author: Sérgio
content:
Avoid these 7 mistakes and build scalable solutions that grow with your business, not against it.

In 2018, Best Buy, a name synonymous with consumer electronics, made a move that few saw coming: it entered the healthcare market.

At first glance, this seemed like an odd direction for the retail giant. But the company, under the leadership of then-CEO Hubert Joly, saw an opportunity.

Best Buy Health’s focus was on helping the elderly age safely at home, tapping into a growing market

forecast to reach $265 billion by 2025

. By 2022, this venture had grown into a $525 million business, with a projected annual growth rate of 35% to 45%.

This wasn’t just a stroke of luck – it was a textbook example of successful scaling. Best Buy didn’t stop at brainstorming or testing ideas. The company moved through the critical stages of innovation: ideation, incubation, and scaling.

While 80% of companies can come up with ideas and test them, only 16% manage to scale them successfully

. So, what’s the secret? How did Best Buy manage to make its venture work while others stumble?

The answer lies in a few key decisions that any company looking to scale needs to get right. Avoiding these seven common pitfalls could be the difference between scaling successfully or falling short. Let’s take a closer look.

What is a scalable solution?

Simply put, scalable solutions are systems or platforms that can handle increased demand – more users, more data, more transactions – without losing performance or maintaining a great experience. They evolve with your business, ensuring you won’t be caught off guard as your needs grow.

That being said, scalability it’s a fundamental business necessity for every company. Yet, too many companies fall into the same traps when trying to build these solutions.

7 key pitfalls to avoid when scaling

Building scalable solutions is crucial for long-term success, but it’s easy to fall into common traps that can slow down your growth.

1. Overcomplicating the architecture from the start

You envision massive success, and your gut tells you to build a system that’s capable of handling millions of users or vast amounts of data. But here’s the catch: trying to over-engineer your system from day one can backfire.

When you layer complexity on top of complexity before you’ve even solved the current problem, your solution will likely become bloated and harder to manage. Scalability doesn’t mean anticipating every possible future scenario; it’s about building a flexible, strong foundation that can grow and adapt as you need it to.

Pro tip:

Start with the essentials. Focus on building a simple, efficient system that solves today’s problems. Add complexity when the need arises, not before.

2. Ignoring the importance of data management

If you’ve ever faced issues with data scaling, you’ll know how crucial this is. A scalable solution isn’t scalable if its data is a mess. Poorly structured data, inconsistent formats, or inefficient storage methods can cause even the most well-designed systems to collapse as they grow.

A common mistake? Putting off a solid

data management

strategy until it’s too late. But when your data starts piling up, the lack of a strong foundation can grind everything to a halt.

Pro tip:

Design your data architecture with scalability in mind from the beginning. Structure your data well, plan for growth, and ensure your system can handle more sources and types of data without falling apart.

3. Believing low-code can’t scale

Low-code platforms are often dismissed as tools for simple apps or quick prototypes, with critics claiming they crumble under the pressure of large-scale, complex demands.

This misconception leads businesses to overlook low-code as a viable solution for enterprise-level challenges. Worse, it can result in underestimating the potential of the platform, leading to poor implementation practices, lack of governance, or over-reliance on default templates that don’t optimize performance.

The reality is that modern

low-code

platforms are built for scalability. With the right architecture, thoughtful design, and adherence to best practices, they can handle high transaction volumes, integrate with other enterprise systems, and support long-term growth. In fact,

low-code often accelerates scaling

by reducing development cycles and allowing for rapid adjustments.

[Sd3]

[BB4]

Pro tip:

Treat low-code with the same strategic rigor as any other development approach. Partnering with experts like

Near Partner

, who understand the nuances of low-code platforms, can make all the difference.

4. Underestimating the impact of third-party integrations

Third-party tools and services can give your business a huge boost, but relying too heavily on them without considering long-term scalability is a major pitfall. Many companies make the mistake of integrating tools that work fine initially

,

but start to buckle when the volume increases. Will that payment processor still work when you have 100,000 customers, or are you going to be stuck with performance issues and slowdowns that frustrate both you and your users?

Pro tip:

Always check if third-party services can scale along with your needs. Don’t just settle for what works today – look for long-term solutions that can grow with you, and plan for the possibility of having to switch if your needs evolve.

5. Failure to test for scalability early on

Far too often, companies wait until their system is overwhelmed to realize that it can’t handle the growth. By then, it’s too late to fix without significant downtime or a complete overhaul.

Not testing for scalability early means you’re blind to potential bottlenecks, inefficient processes, or weak points in your system that could be disastrous down the line. So, don’t wait for problems to arise – test

before

you need to scale, not after you’re already knee-deep in a crisis.

Pro tip:

Implement performance and stress testing from the very beginning. Simulate real-world scenarios where your system is expected to grow and monitor how it performs. The earlier you identify weak points, the easier it is to fix them.

6. Neglecting to plan for maintenance and support

Once you build a scalable solution, the work doesn’t stop. Maintaining a scalable solution requires constant monitoring, troubleshooting, and fine-tuning. If you forget about this aspect, your system might run smoothly at first but deteriorate quickly under increased load.

Pro tip:

Plan for regular monitoring and maintenance.

Automate routine tasks

, stay ahead of performance issues, and ensure you have the team in place to handle emerging problems as they arise.

7. Scaling too quickly without the right resources

It’s exciting when things start to take off, and the temptation to scale rapidly can be overwhelming. But scaling too quickly without the necessary expertise or infrastructure can cause you to outgrow your own resources, leading to stress, mismanagement, and ultimately a solution that’s not up to par.

Pro Tip:

Make sure your infrastructure, team, and processes are ready for growth. Don’t rush into scaling; be sure you’ve got the foundation and support necessary to manage the added complexity.

Building scalable solutions: a step-by-step guide

Here’s a step-by-step approach to building scalable solutions that stand the test of time.Here’s a step-by-step approach to building scalable solutions that stand the test of time.

1. Start with a future-proof data architecture

Your data architecture is the backbone of scalability. A poorly planned structure can create bottlenecks as your data volume grows.

One critical aspect of scalability is ensuring that requests from the Frontend are not lost due to timeouts. Properly allocating resources to handle these requests is essential. An architecture based on Domain-Driven Development (DDD) or microservices can help optimize this allocation by prioritizing the most frequently used services.

Additionally, in the backend, adopting asynchronous communication using protocols such as AMQP is highly recommended to ensure that:

Each service operates independently, avoiding direct dependencies that could hinder execution.

Requests between services are stored until they are processed, preventing any loss of data.

What to do:

Choose a modular, cloud-native architecture. Use relational databases for structured data and NoSQL for unstructured or highly dynamic data. Implement indexing strategies and partitioning to optimize query performance.

At Near Partner, we have successfully applied these principles in projects like

De Grisogono

, where we built a scalable solution capable of handling high-performance demands while ensuring reliability and efficiency. By leveraging a well-structured architecture and the right data management strategies, we created a system that meets business needs while remaining resilient under load.

2. Design for integration from the ground up

Scalable solutions rarely exist in isolation. Your system must play well with others, such as CRM software, analytics tools, or third-party APIs.

What to do

: Choose APIs and applications with strong documentation, version control, and flexibility for future upgrades. Ensure your integration strategy supports asynchronous communication to prevent bottlenecks.

3. Build secure and scalable access management

As your user base grows, managing access and permissions becomes more complex. Neglect this, and scalability becomes a security nightmare.

What to do

: Implement role-based access control (RBAC) and single sign-on (SSO). Use identity providers like Okta or Azure AD for centralizing user authentication.

Considering the

Tupperware

project, Near Partner implemented the role-based access control (RBAC) model to ensure detailed and efficient access management, allowing users to view information, access menus, and perform actions based on the specific permissions associated with their roles. This also added significant flexibility to how permissions are managed and how responsibilities are assigned to individuals overseeing various processes, optimizing the management of hierarchies within the extensive ecosystem.

4. Optimize your backend infrastructure

One critical aspect of scalability is ensuring that requests from the Frontend are not lost due to timeouts. Properly allocating resources to handle these requests is essential. An architecture based on Domain-Driven Development (DDD) or microservices can help optimize this allocation by prioritizing the most frequently used services.

Additionally, in the backend, adopting asynchronous communication using protocols such as AMQP is highly recommended to ensure that:

Each service operates independently, avoiding direct dependencies that could hinder execution.

Requests between services are stored until they are processed, preventing any loss of data.

By implementing these strategies, teams can build resilient and scalable solutions that efficiently handle high loads and maintain system reliability.

What to do

: Add load balancers to distribute traffic efficiently and implement auto-scaling on cloud platforms like AWS or Azure.

5. Implement strong governance for low-code development

Low-code platforms can scale if managed well, but without governance, they can become a nightmare of redundant apps and inefficiencies.

What to do

: Define coding standards, enforce version control, and monitor platform performance. Train your teams to design for scalability within the low-code framework.

6. Plan for elastic scalability in the cloud

Scalability today almost always involves the cloud. But moving to the cloud without a clear strategy can lead to overprovisioning (wasting resources) or underprovisioning (performance issues).

What to do

: Use cloud services with elastic scalability, such as serverless computing or container orchestration. Implement cost management tools to avoid runaway bills.

7. Test, monitor, and iterate

Scalability isn’t a one-time effort; it’s an ongoing process. Systems that scale today might struggle tomorrow as technology evolves and demands change.

What to do

: Stress-test your systems regularly, simulate peak loads, and refine based on real-world data. Set up automated alerts for key performance indicators.

Ready to build smart, scalable solutions?

The road to scalable solutions is full of potential pitfalls, but avoiding these seven mistakes will put you on the path to sustainable growth. By focusing on simplicity, maintaining data integrity, ensuring your third-party tools can scale, testing early, planning for ongoing support, and not rushing to scale without the right resources, you’ll be building a system that can evolve with your business.

At

Near Partner

, we specialize in

software development

,

low-code solutions

, and

Salesforce consultancy

, ensuring that the solutions we build are not only scalable but also practical and future-proof.

Reach out today

and let us help you build the foundation that can support your business as it grows.

There are 18 default colour palettes available, or you can custom a palette based on the main colours from the logo of your company. OutSystems also allows you to customize font, structure and shape, as well as the login screen background. You can also find built-in screen templates ready to use for developing your applications. You can choose from a different set of Web Screen Templates and Mobile Screen Templates.

For instance, a multi-tenant SaaS platform can leverage OutSystems’ Theme Editor to customize the user interface for each client, ensuring that their app’s branding is consistent with their company’s identity without coding changes.

6. Integration with External Services ad Robust API

OutSystems can integrate applications with external services such as databases, social media platforms, and cloud storage. This allows you to access and use data from these services within your applications, without worrying about data migration. OutSystems provides seamless integration via SOAP, REST, or SAP APIs making it easier for developers to access data in new, meaningful ways. Exposing data is even simpler, extensive support for APIs, OutSystems makes it easy to build your own integrations. This can be done either with REST APIs or SOAP web services without hard coding.

7. Advanced Data Visualization

What if we told you could produce professional-looking reports and dashboards in your app in hours rather than weeks? From charts to maps, with HTML5 or JavaScript, developers can use OutSystems’ advanced data visualization tools to extract more information from data. Most of these reporting tools work seamlessly across desktop browsers or mobile devices. Developers can thus focus on insights’ analyses and spend less time taking care of technical implementations.

If you work on more advanced scenarios, OutSystems can step it up as well. Its open architecture excels integrates fully with the vast majority of business intelligence or data reporting tools. All it takes is a standard SQL Server or Oracle database.

Imagine a healthcare provider using OutSystems. It allows to create a dashboard that displays real-time patient data in charts, maps, and graphs, enabling health professionals to make informed decisions quickly.

8. Multi-Language Support

OutSystems also supports applications in multiple languages. You can define a primary language, and add multiple secondary languages that vary from region to region. This means you can create apps catered to a global audience. The platform supports dynamic language switching, ensuring customers can shop in their preferred language.

9. Automated deployment

OutSystems supports automated deployment and continuous integration. This means a development team can automate the deployment process of their app across different environments. For instance, when a new feature is developed or a bug is fixed, the app can be automatically tested and deployed to production with minimal manual intervention, reducing the risk of errors and speeding up time to market.

10. Native app development

OutSystems also enables the creation of native mobile apps for iOS and Android, streamlining mobile app development through its drag-and-drop interface and pre-built components.

Is OutSystems for You?

If you’re looking to accelerate your digital transformation, streamline app development, and ensure high-quality user experiences, OutSystems could be the right platform for you.

Overall, OutSystems is a smart choice for organizations aiming to develop scalable and secure apps faster. Its low-code platform allows even non-developers to contribute, speeding up time-to-market. If your business requires complex, multi-channel solutions that integrate seamlessly across web and mobile platforms, OutSystems offers the necessary tools.

However, it may not be the right fit for every business, so it’s important to assess your specific needs before committing.

title: Fast, flexible, and future-ready: what customer journeys should look like
author: Sérgio
content:
No one needs “business as usual”. It’s time to redesign your customer journey and see how loyalty truly sticks.

It’s 2014 and

Anne Boden

, a top exec at a major multinational bank, has just walked away from her cushy, secure role. Why? Because she’s tired of the outdated, customer-last approach of traditional banking. Armed with guts, a bit of frustration, and a consultancy team, she maps out the so-called “customer journey” of bank clients. What she finds is a mess of inefficiencies and “pain points” that make no sense.

Fast-forward to today, and Boden’s Starling Bank isn’t just thriving – it’s a key player in the financial world, crowned the UK’s best bank four years running. The secret? Ripping up the old customer journey playbook and designing a fresh, intuitive path for modern users. Anne Boden didn’t just tweak a few processes; she completely reimagined the system and started a movement. And it all began with rethinking the customer journey.

So, let’s start from the top. What exactly is a customer journey, and why should you care? More importantly, how can you leverage tools to create a journey that goes beyond expectations? Let’s find out.

What is a customer journey, really?

The customer journey is a sequence of touchpoints that begins even before a person becomes a customer. It starts with brand awareness, progressing to a purchase, and ideally, culminating in lasting loyalty. By analysing and optimizing this journey, businesses gain insights into their

customers’ experiences

, enabling them to enhance every interaction along the way.

In a world where trust is harder to earn than ever, optimizing every single touchpoint isn’t optional – it’s the difference between being the brand people rave about – or the one they ghost.

Why does it matter?

Here’s why mastering your customer journey is critical.

1. Retention is the new acquisition

Acquiring new customers is expensive –

up to five times more costly than retaining existing ones

. A well-crafted customer journey ensures satisfaction and fosters loyalty, turning one-time buyers into repeat customers. Loyal customers spend more, refer others, and act as advocates for your brand.

2. Experience is the ultimate differentiator

Products and services can be copied, but a stellar experience is unique to your brand. In fact,

73% of customers say that experience is a key factor in their purchasing decisions

. When you prioritize the customer journey, you’re doing more than just selling a product – you’re delivering value and building trust.

3. Revenue follows relationships

A seamless, engaging customer journey directly impacts your bottom line. Studies show that brands with a good customer experience can

increase revenue by 2–7%

. Every interaction – from the first click to post-purchase follow-ups – can be optimized to drive conversions and revenue.

4. Customer journeys give out valuable inputs

Your customer journey is a

goldmine of data

. Tracking behaviours, preferences, and pain points provides invaluable insights to refine your strategy. This data helps you predict future trends, personalize interactions, and stay ahead of the competition.

Key elements of the customer journey

Here are the elements to be mastered to create an unforgettable experience.

1. Awareness

This is where it all begins. How do potential customers discover your brand? It could be through an ad, a social media post, or a recommendation from a friend. Effective SEO, well-targeted advertisements, and a strong online presence can ensure your brand gets noticed. The goal here is to spark curiosity and make a memorable first impression.

2. Consideration

At this stage, customers are evaluating their options. What makes your brand stand out? High-quality, personalized content such as case studies, testimonials, and engaging product demonstrations can make all the difference. Stellar reviews and competitive advantages should shine here, to build confidence in your offering.

3. Purchase

This is the make-or-break moment. Is the buying process smooth, intuitive, and secure? A seamless checkout process with multiple payment options can significantly reduce cart abandonment rates. Eliminate unnecessary friction – because even the smallest hiccup can send customers running to your competitors.

4. Post-purchase

The journey doesn’t end when the transaction is complete. Post-purchase is your chance to turn a customer into a loyal advocate. Strategies like personalized thank-you emails, proactive customer support, and loyalty programs keep customers engaged and coming back for more. This stage is also crucial for gathering feedback to refine future interactions.

Here’s a visual breakdown of a customer journey mapping, highlighting key touchpoints, essential stages, and the channels that shape the experience.

How to create an exceptional customer journey

It’s time to create a strategy that’s data-driven, customer-centric, and tech-empowered. Here’s how to make it happen.

1. Understand your customers inside and out

Before you design anything, you need to know who you’re designing for. Gather insights about your customers – what motivates them, what frustrates them, and what they value most. Use surveys, analytics, and interviews to get a crystal-clear picture of their needs.

Actionable steps:

Develop buyer personas:

Create detailed profiles representing your ideal customers, including demographics, pain points, and behaviours.

Analyse customer data:

Leverage tools like Salesforce

to pull data from multiple sources and identify patterns in customer interactions.

Listen actively:

Pay attention to social media comments, support tickets, and feedback forms to understand your audience’s real-time needs.

2. Map the journey, from start to finish

A journey map is your blueprint. It visualizes every interaction a customer has with your brand, from discovery to loyalty. Don’t sugarcoat it – be honest about where the gaps and pain points are.

Actionable steps:

List all touchpoints:

Identify every place your customers interact with your brand. It could be ads, websites, apps, support teams, among others.

Assess the flow:

Map out how customers move from one stage to the next. Are there bottlenecks or unnecessary friction?

Use tools to simulate the journey:

Low-code platforms

can quickly help you prototype and test improved workflows without overhauling your entire system.

3. Prioritize personalization

Today’s customers expect experiences that feel tailored to them, but there’s a fine line between helpful and intrusive. Use the data you’ve gathered to create meaningful interactions at every stage of the user journey.

Actionable steps:

Segment your audience:

Group customers based on shared characteristics and preferences to deliver more relevant experiences.

Automate smart recommendations:

Tools like

Salesforce AI

can recommend products or services based on past behaviours therefore increasing conversion rates.

Keep it real-time:

Personalization works best when it’s immediate – whether it’s a dynamic email, custom landing page, or in-app message.

4. Streamline processes for speed and simplicity

Customers are impatient. If they hit a roadblock, they’ll move on. Simplify every step of the journey, from discovery to post-purchase, to keep them engaged.

Actionable steps:

Eliminate unnecessary steps:

Audit your processes and remove redundancies. For instance, cut down on the number of clicks needed to make a purchase.

Integrate systems seamlessly:

Use custom software to connect your

CRM

, e-commerce platform, and

communication tools

for a frictionless experience.

Offer self-service options:

Let customers solve simple issues on their own with FAQs, chatbots, or an intuitive help center.

5. Gather feedback and iterate continuously

Your user journey is a breathing system that requires constant attention. Collect feedback regularly and use it to refine the experience.

Actionable steps:

Monitor customer satisfaction:

Use surveys like NPS (Net Promoter Score) to gauge how happy your customers are.

Track KPIs:

Keep an eye on metrics

like conversion rates, churn rates, and average resolution times to spot issues early.

Test and optimize:

Run A/B tests on different touchpoints to see what works best and adjust accordingly.

6. Future-proof your journey

Technology and customer expectations change rapidly. Ensure your journey evolves by building a framework that’s flexible, scalable, and ready to adapt.

Actionable steps:

Adopt omnichannel strategies:

Create a unified experience across all channels, from apps to in-store touchpoints.

Use predictive analytics:

Data is the fuel that drives a future-ready customer journey. Leverage data tools like

Salesforce

to anticipate customer needs and act proactively.

Invest in scalable technology:

Build custom software that can grow with your business without requiring constant reinvention.

Time to transform: where do you start?

Creating a fast, flexible, and future-ready customer journey is a necessity. And the best part? You don’t have to do it alone.

At

Near Partner

, we specialize in crafting customer journeys that deliver real results. Whether through cutting-edge

software development

, intuitive low-code platforms, or Salesforce consultancy, we have the expertise to help you:

Because when your customer journey thrives, so does your business.

Let’s talk

.

title: 14 major telecom challenges (and how to beat them)
author: Sérgio
content:
Telecom’s challenges are everywhere, from AI to security. Here are our top 14 picks and how to beat them.

From aging infrastructure to cybersecurity threats, from AI integration to customer expectations that never stop rising, telecom companies are juggling complexity at every level. The pressure to modernize, stay competitive, and deliver flawless service is relentless.

In this article, we break down

14 of the biggest challenges facing telecom today

— and more importantly,

how forward-thinking companies are overcoming them

.

1. Updating age-old systems without breaking the bank

Telecom companies have long been burdened by outdated legacy systems – monolithic infrastructures designed for an era that no longer exists. While these systems may still function, they create massive roadblocks to modernization, operational efficiency, and cybersecurity. The industry’s reliance on aging technology is a key challenge in delivering the agile, data-driven services that modern consumers and businesses expect.

Why it’s a problem:

Legacy systems require extensive resources to maintain, draining budgets that could otherwise be invested in innovation.

These systems do not seamlessly connect with modern digital platforms, leading to inefficiencies and poor user experiences.

Outdated technology is a prime target for cybercriminals, increasing the risk of data breaches and service disruptions.

How to win:

A full-scale infrastructure overhaul is often impractical, both in terms of cost and operational disruption. Instead, a strategic modernization approach is key:

Adopt API-driven integrations:

Implement APIs to enable

legacy systems

to communicate with modern digital solutions, bridging the gap without requiring a full system replacement.

Prioritize cloud migration:

Shifting to cloud-based services enhances agility, scalability, and cost efficiency, making it easier to deploy new capabilities quickly.

Embrace microservices architecture:

Breaking down monolithic systems into modular, independent components enables faster updates and innovation without overhauling the entire system.

2. Dealing with rising customer expectations and lower price points

Today’s telecom customers have zero patience for friction. If their billing experience feels like deciphering hieroglyphics, they’ll switch providers fast.

Why it’s a problem:

Customers demand hyper-personalized, omnichannel experiences.

Frustration with slow support or confusing services leads to churn.

AI-powered competitors are setting new benchmarks in CX.

How to win:

Deploy AI-driven customer insights:

Use

predictive analytics

to anticipate issues and address them before customers even notice.

Invest in self-service platforms:

Empower customers with AI chatbots, interactive FAQs, and automated troubleshooting to reduce dependency on human support agents.

Optimize real-time issue resolution:

Implement intelligent ticketing systems and automated workflows to accelerate problem resolution.

3. Why Telecoms Must Prioritize Cybersecurity

As telecom companies accelerate digital transformation, they also become more attractive targets for cybercriminals. The vast amounts of sensitive customer data, coupled with increasingly interconnected networks, make

cybersecurity

a top priority.

Why it’s a problem:

Telecom providers store extensive personal and financial data, making them prime candidates for cyberattacks.

The growth of 5G, IoT, and cloud services introduces more potential vulnerabilities.

Cybercriminals continually refine their tactics, using AI-driven attacks, ransomware, and persistent threats to breach defenses.

How to win:

Adopt a zero-trust security model:

Assume all network traffic is potentially malicious and enforce strict access controls.

Implement real-time threat monitoring:

Real-time monitoring and AI-driven threat detection can stop attacks in their tracks before they cause any harm.

Automate incident response:

Use automated systems to respond to breaches instantly, minimizing potential harm.

Train employees continuously:

Phishing attacks are one of the easiest ways hackers get in. Your employees need to know how to spot them.

4. Bypassing the “we’ve always done it this way” mindset

Technology is one thing. People are the real challenge. Employees stuck in their ways often resist change, dragging their feet when it comes to adopting new tools and processes. If your team isn’t fully on board with your transformation goals, your technology investments will be wasted.

Why it’s a problem:

Hesitant employees can prevent companies from realizing the full benefits of new technologies.

Traditional corporate cultures can become insular, making it difficult to innovate at speed.

Employees who lack digital skills will slow down your progress, forcing you to play catch-up.

How to win:

Foster a mindset of innovation:

Don’t just tell people about change. Show them the benefits. Make digital transformation exciting, not scary.

Upskill your workforce:

Continuous learning and development should be a core part of your strategy.

Empower teams to lead change:

Involve employees from day one, give them a voice, and provide incentives for digital-first thinking.

5. Keeping up with constantly changing rules

Telecom is one of the most heavily regulated sectors in the world. GDPR, FCC rules, data sovereignty laws – keeping up with the constantly shifting landscape of regulations is like trying to hit a moving target. But miss, and the consequences can be severe: heavy fines, legal action, and a damaged reputation.

Why it’s a problem:

What’s compliant in one country could be a violation in another, making global operations challenging.

The laws governing telecom are constantly evolving, often with little notice.

The fines and penalties for breaking regulations can be devastating.

How to win:

Automate regulatory tracking:

Use AI and regulatory tech to stay on top of rule changes in real time.

Partner with legal tech firms:

Stay ahead by collaborating with firms that specialize in telecom regulations.

Integrate compliance into business operations:

Compliance shouldn’t be an afterthought. Make it part of your digital transformation journey, and you’ll be ready.

6. Dealing with coverage outages

You’re offering connectivity, but what happens when your service

disconnects

at the worst possible moment? Coverage outages are not just an inconvenience, they’re a trust killer. One bad experience could send your customers straight to the competition. In an era where 5G promises seamless connections, you can’t afford to drop calls.

Why it’s a problem:

People are more dependent than ever on their telecom service, whether for work, personal communication, or emergency needs. Interruptions are unacceptable.

Enterprises rely heavily on telecom services for operations. A loss of connectivity can bring business activities to a grinding halt.

The cost of downtime for telecom companies – both in terms of lost revenue and damage to brand loyalty – is massive.

How to win:

Enhance network resilience

: Invest in infrastructure that can dynamically reroute traffic or self-heal in case of disruptions.

Implement predictive maintenance

: Use AI to predict failures before they cripple your operations.

Improve communication during outages

: Don’t go silent during service disruptions. Use proactive communication to keep them informed and manage expectations.

7. Finding the right skills

The competition for skilled workers is fierce everywhere and telecom companies are not immune. Attracting and retaining the right employees is and will become increasingly difficult.

Why it’s a problem:

AI developers, data scientists, and cybersecurity experts are in high demand, and short supply.

Many current employees lack the advanced digital skills necessary for a successful transformation.

The best talent is constantly being poached by other industries, which leaves telecoms struggling to hold onto key players.

How to win:

Invest in training and development:

Upskilling existing employees not only fills the gap but also fosters loyalty.

Leverage remote work:

Expand your talent pool by hiring from a broader geographical range.

Create a competitive work environment:

Offer incentives like flexible working hours, professional development opportunities, and career growth paths to attract and retain top talent.

8. Reducing your environment footprint

Telecom’s carbon footprint may not get the bad press other industries do, but it’s massive. In an age where sustainability is an expectation, sticking with outdated, energy-hungry infrastructure is a PR disaster waiting to happen.

Why it’s a problem:

With infrastructure that’s often outdated, your carbon footprint is growing, while your customers’ concerns about sustainability are increasing.

Consumers, especially younger generations, are actively seeking companies that prioritize sustainability.

Governments worldwide are tightening environmental regulations. Failure to adapt could result in fines, lawsuits, or even reputation-damaging campaigns.

How to win:

Green your operations:

Transition to renewable energy sources, reduce waste, and embrace energy-efficient technologies. Show your customers that your commitment to sustainability is as strong as your network.

Communicate your efforts:

Don’t wait for criticism. Let your customers know the steps you’re taking to reduce your environmental impact. Transparency builds trust.

9. Delivering true empathy

Customer service

in telecom is often the first and last line of defense for customer loyalty. And yet, many telecom companies still rely on outdated, clunky support models that frustrate customers and push them straight into the arms of competitors. It’s no longer enough to simply be responsive; today’s consumers expect instant, personalized service.

Why it’s a problem:

Endless hold times, unhelpful agents, and the dreaded “press 1 for this” make telecom support a nightmare. When service is this painful, customer loss is almost inevitable.

One bad interaction can undo years of trust-building. Negative experiences get shared, retweeted, and discussed across every social platform – with no second chances.

Meanwhile, your competitors are embracing AI-driven support that’s instant, intelligent, and personal. While you’re still trapped in traditional service models, they’re already ahead, offering customers everything they want, right when they need it.

How to win:

Create proactive experiences:

Predict and resolve problems before customers even notice. Use customer insights to anticipate their needs and offer solutions ahead of time. Be the provider that sees the issues before they do.

Train like your business depends on it (it does):

Equip your staff with the right training and tools to provide immediate, personalized service. Real empathy and efficiency are the real game changers in customer service.

10. Bringing AI into daily operations

AI promises efficiency, but too often, it ends up as just another tool employees struggle to use. If it doesn’t integrate seamlessly, adoption stalls, productivity suffers, and investments go to waste. The challenge isn’t AI itself, it’s how you bring it into daily workflows.

Why it’s a problem:

If AI isn’t intuitive, it slows teams down instead of speeding them up.

Employees won’t adopt AI if it feels like an extra burden.

AI initiatives often get stuck in test phases, never delivering real impact.

How to win:

Make AI invisible.

Embed it into existing systems so it works in the background, not as an extra step.

Prioritize ease of use.

If AI doesn’t feel effortless, people won’t use it.

Deploy, refine, scale.

Start small, optimize based on real use, and expand intelligently.

11. Managing Field Services effortlessly

Coordinating field teams, ensuring service quality, and managing logistics in real time is no small task. Without the right tools, inefficiencies pile up – missed appointments, frustrated customers, and escalating cost.

Why it’s a problem:

Scheduling, dispatching, and tracking field teams is complex and prone to errors.

Delays and miscommunication can quickly damage trust and satisfaction.

Without real-time insights, decision-making is reactive instead of strategic.

How to win:

Centralize and automate.

Smart scheduling and AI-powered routing reduce inefficiencies.

Keep teams connected.

Real-time communication and mobile access improve service execution.

Use data for smarter decisions.

Predictive insights help optimize operations before problems arise.

Partner with experts.

Near Partner delivers the solutions to take field service management from reactive to proactive.

12. Making the most of what you already have

You’ve invested in powerful platforms like Salesforce and Microsoft, but are you truly extracting their full value? Too often, businesses underutilize their existing tools, leaving efficiency and growth potential on the table.

Why it’s a problem:

Many features remain unused, limiting productivity and ROI.

Disconnected tools create inefficiencies and hinder collaboration.

If teams aren’t fully leveraging the technology, performance suffers.

How to win:

Optimize configurations.

Fine-tune settings and workflows to align with business goals.

Enhance integration.

Connect platforms for seamless data flow and smarter decision-making.

Empower your teams.

Provide training and support to drive full adoption.

13. Accelerating implementation

Waiting months or years for a custom-built solution is a luxury you can’t afford anymore. Traditional development could be holding your business back, while competitors are using low-code platforms and AI for speeding things up – without sacrificing flexibility or control.

Why it’s a problem:

Custom solutions often require months, or years, to go live.

Backlogs grow as demand for new applications outpaces resources.

Static systems can’t keep up with evolving market demands.

How to win:

Leverage low-code platforms.

Build and deploy applications quickly with minimal coding.

Embed AI for smarter automation.

Reduce manual work and enhance decision-making.

Empower non-developers.

Give business teams the tools to create solutions without relying solely on IT.

14. Managing the social impact of AI

AI is not just disrupting technology; it’s trembling the very foundations of society. The rise of automation and AI threatens to wipe out jobs, create ethical nightmares, and erode public trust if not managed correctly. The way you handle AI’s social impact will define your company’s future.

Why it’s a problem:

AI comes with job displacements. New roles will emerge, but some will vanish. Are you prepared to guide your team through this shift?

AI raises questions about privacy, fairness, and transparency – issues that need your attention now

Consumers are watching closely. They want to know how their data is being used and how AI decisions affect them.

How to win:

Reskill your workforce.

Equip your teams with the skills they need to thrive alongside AI, ensuring they’re part of the solution, not the casualty.

Lead with ethics.

Embrace AI in a way that prioritizes fairness and transparency. Being responsible is essential for building long-term trust.

Communicate openly.

Be transparent about how AI is shaping your business and how it benefits customers. Lead the conversation and show you’re in control of the change.

A real-world example: how we helped QMC overcome Telecom challenges with Salesforce

QMC is a global leader in telecom with over 2,400 assets, is revolutionizing communication with cutting-edge technologies like 5G, AI, IoT, and virtual reality. Their diverse clients include municipalities, airports, hospitals, and shopping malls. However, even the biggest players in telecom face challenges that can stall growth and impact service delivery.

QMC’s global operations were plagued by disjointed systems. Sales teams struggled to manage leads, proposals, and contracts effectively. Meanwhile, field teams faced difficulties tracking installations and maintenance across various regions. The lack of structure and organization resulted in inefficiencies that directly impacted customer satisfaction and business performance.

We started by overhauling QMC’s sales process. With

Salesforce

and

Next, we focused on operations. A tailored workflow for task management, reporting, and maintenance tracking improved overall efficiency. The result was better coordination, faster project implementation, and a standardized onboarding process that supported QMC’s rapid growth.

QMC has completely redefined how they operate, transforming from a fragmented system into a powerhouse of efficiency across teams and continents. By centralizing their data, they’ve shattered silos, improved internal communication, and redefined project execution. The payoff? A telecom giant that’s not just keeping up with the demands of a rapidly growing market, but outpacing the competition with agility, scalability, and a laser-focus on customer success. QMC just saw what real transformation looks like.

Manual data entry? Lead scoring? Basic customer inquiries? AI handles the monotonous tasks, so your teams can focus on strategy, relationships, and big-picture thinking. In the near future, these agents are expected to take on even more complex tasks, enabling more personalized and efficient interactions.

Through its innovative solutions, Salesforce not only optimizes customer service but also prepares businesses for a future where artificial intelligence will be a central pillar in creating exceptional customer experiences.

enhance efficiency

, reduce response times, and deliver

.

Marketing, customer service, and operations teams that want to fine-tune AI-driven conversations to improve engagement and efficiency.

4. Salesforce Data Cloud: your data, unified and weaponized

Enterprises, data-driven organizations, and leaders who need a unified, real-time view of their business to drive strategy and execution.

Traditional analytics provide data; Einstein Analytics provides answers. It applies advanced AI models to identify patterns, predict trends, and recommend actions.

Ideal for:

Executives, analysts, and business leaders who need deeper insights to stay ahead of the competition.

6. Einstein Voice: stop typing, start doing

Einstein Voice allows users to interact with Salesforce using natural speech, making it easy to perform tasks like updating records, retrieving information, and executing commands, simply by speaking. Whether you’re in the middle of a meeting, on the go, or hands full in the field, Einstein Voice helps you stay productive without needing to type.

For example, a sales professional can update a client’s contact information while driving to their next meeting, or a field team can log important notes directly into the system after visiting a client, all without having to stop what they’re doing. Executives can quickly ask for sales reports or performance insights during a call, without needing to manually search for data.

Ideal for:

Sales professionals, field teams, and executives who need quick access to information, hands-free data entry, and the ability to multitask effectively while on the move.

7. Einstein Bots: chatbots that know what customers want

Automating customer interactions through

chatbots

doesn’t mean sacrificing quality. Einstein Bots use AI to engage with customers across multiple channels, answering common inquiries, resolving issues, and seamlessly escalating complex cases to human agents when necessary.

Ideal for:

Customer service teams, support managers, and businesses that want to scale their customer engagement while maintaining a high-quality service experience.

Best practices for implementing Salesforce AI tools

AI is only as powerful as the way you use it. To get real results, instead of just another layer of tech, follow these best practices when implementing Salesforce AI tools:

1. Start with a clear goal (not just “let’s use AI”)

AI can be a game changer, but it’s important to define a clear objective before jumping in. Whether your goal is improving lead conversion, automating customer support, or refining marketing campaigns, AI should align with your business needs. Remember, AI is a tool, not a strategy.

Start small. Begin with one focused use case, and iterate as you go. This allows your team to become comfortable with the technology and its outputs. As you gain confidence, you can gradually expand its capabilities, adding more functionalities over time. By evolving in this way, you ensure smoother adoption and better results as your AI systems grow.

2. Clean up your data first

AI thrives on quality data. If your CRM is full of duplicates, outdated contacts, or incomplete records, AI won’t magically fix it. Invest time in data hygiene so your AI models can deliver real insights instead of incorrect predictions.

3. Integrate seamlessly

AI works best when it’s connected across your entire Salesforce ecosystem. Ensure your AI tools sync with CRM, marketing, sales, and service platforms to create a

unified, intelligent workflow

.

4. Automate, but keep a human touch

AI is great at handling repetitive tasks, but some interactions still

need a human element

. Use AI to enhance – not replace – your team, ensuring automation supports meaningful, personalized customer experiences.

5. Train your team

Provide training so teams understand how to interpret AI-driven insights, adjust automation settings, and use AI as a strategic advantage.

6. Monitor, optimize, repeat

Track performance, refine processes, and tweak AI models as your business evolves. The more you fine-tune, the smarter your AI becomes.

title: Agentforce lets you build AI agents in Salesforce
author: Daniel Pinho
content:
Agentforce lets you build custom AI agents directly in Salesforce using your own data and workflows. Learn how it works, what you can do with it, and how to get started.

Agentforce is a new way to build AI agents directly inside Salesforce, powered by your data, logic, and workflows. Whether you’re looking to automate customer support, streamline sales operations, or personalize experiences at scale, Agentforce makes it easy to bring intelligent automation into your existing CRM setup. In this guide, we’ll show you exactly how it works, what it can do, and how to start building your own agents in just a few steps.

What is Agentforce Salesforce?

Agentforce is a

native Salesforce

tool that allows users to create AI agents directly within the Salesforce platform. These agents can understand prompts, take actions, and automate workflows by interacting with Salesforce data and logic — all without needing to leave the CRM environment. Agentforce is built to work with your existing Salesforce setup, including custom objects, flows, Apex code, and permission settings.

Unlike generic AI chatbots, Agentforce agents are deeply integrated into Salesforce, meaning they can perform context-aware tasks like updating records, generating reports, or triggering automations based on real-time input. You can define what the agent knows, what it can do, and how it should behave, making it a flexible solution for automating support, sales, service, or internal operations.

Here are some of the core features that make it a powerful tool for AI-driven CRM automation:

Native Salesforce Integration:

agents run entirely within Salesforce, with full access to your objects, records, flows, Apex classes, and permissions.

Customizable Agent Context:

define exactly what each agent knows, from knowledge base articles to custom object relationships to ensure relevant, accurate responses.

Natural Language Prompting:

users interact with agents using simple, conversational prompts, making complex tasks more accessible to non-technical users.

Secure and Permission-Aware:

agents respect Salesforce security models, so actions are limited by the same profiles and permission sets as human users.

Action-Triggered Automation:

agents can call flows, execute Apex code, or update records based on user prompts enabling real-time, AI-powered workflows.

Usage Monitoring and Feedback:

Admins can review how agents are being used, identify patterns, and refine performance over time with built-in monitoring tools.

Benefits of Agentforce

In Agentforce, an

agent

is an AI-powered assistant that can understand natural language, take action, and interact with your Salesforce data and processes, all based on the rules and context you define. These agents are not just chatbots; they can perform real tasks like updating records, triggering workflows, answering internal questions, or guiding users through complex processes. Because they run natively in Salesforce, they work seamlessly with your existing objects, automations, and security settings.

The main benefit of Agentforce is that it brings intelligent automation into your CRM without needing custom code or third-party integrations. You can build agents tailored to your business needs, whether to handle common support requests, assist sales teams, or provide internal help desk functionality. Agents are easy to create, customizable, and context-aware, helping teams save time, reduce errors, and deliver faster, more consistent responses across the board.

Limitations of Agentforce

While Agentforce is powerful, it’s not a plug-and-play solution for every use case. Agents rely on well-defined prompts, context, and access to the right Salesforce data to be effective — which means some setup and iteration is required. If your data model is inconsistent or your workflows are complex, agents might struggle to return accurate results without fine-tuning.

Another limitation is scope. Agentforce agents are designed to operate within the Salesforce ecosystem, so they’re not ideal for tasks that require integration with external tools or systems unless additional development is done. Also, while no-code configuration is a key benefit, building high-performing agents still requires someone who understands how your Salesforce environment works — which may limit adoption for non-technical users without support.

Agentforce: Real-World Applications

By combining AI with native Salesforce capabilities, Agentforce makes it possible to streamline work in ways that are both intelligent and secure. Here are a few real-world applications:

Customer Support:

Agents can answer common customer queries, update case records, and route issues to the right team — reducing response times and freeing up human agents for complex problems.

Sales Enablement:

Sales teams can use agents to summarize account history, update opportunities, log call notes, or even suggest next-best actions, all via natural language prompts.

Internal Help Desk:

Employees can interact with an internal AI agent to get answers about company policies, submit IT requests, or update HR information — without needing to navigate multiple systems.

Marketing Operations:

Agents can pull campaign performance data, generate reports, or automate common workflows like list segmentation or lead assignment.

Field Service & Logistics:

Technicians or coordinators can use AI agents to check inventory, schedule visits, or log service notes — all on the go, through a prompt-based interface.

How to get started with Agentforce

Getting started with Agentforce begins inside your Salesforce setup. First, make sure you have access to Agentforce (currently available in select editions or via pilot programs). From there, you can create your first agent directly within Salesforce by defining its

purpose

,

data access

, and

permissions

. You’ll also set up the

context

, which tells the agent what it knows — for example, which objects it can access or what internal documentation it should reference.

Once your agent is created, you can test it right away using natural language prompts. From there, refine its behavior by configuring which flows, Apex classes, or automations it can trigger. Salesforce provides tools to monitor and adjust how the agent performs over time, so you can continuously improve its usefulness. No additional tools or integrations are needed — everything runs natively within the Salesforce platform.

Customizing Your Agentforce

One of Agentforce’s biggest strengths is its flexibility — you can customize agents to align with your specific business logic, processes, and data model. This includes defining what the agent “knows” (such as product info, internal documentation, or customer data), what it can “do” (like trigger flows, update records, or escalate cases), and how it should respond to user prompts. You can also set guardrails to ensure it respects role-based permissions and only takes actions that are secure and compliant with your internal policies.

That being said, building truly effective agents often requires more than just enabling the feature. Near Partner

title: Software Development Outsourcing: Offshore or Nearshore?!
author: Patricia
content:
If you navigate the complex waters of software development, it is highly likely that you came across terms like outsourcing destinations, offshore and nearshore outsourcing. While images of shores and beaches came to mind, it all sounds confusing when the conversation topic is software… Don’t worry. Help is on the way!

Let’s start from the basics.

In a nutshell, software development outsourcing is when a business hires a third-party company or developer(s) to handle information technology tasks, like building a solution from scratch or providing an extra pair of hands to their internal development team.

What software development outsourcing means today

Even though software development outsourcing has been here for decades, nowadays it is a crucial tactic for any organization who wants to keep up or keep ahead in technology.

Not long ago, organizations used outsourcing to improve back-office operations through cost reduction and performance improvement. Today, outsourcing solutions are enabling competitive advantage by accelerating changes within those organizations that have the audacity and skill to leap over the technology chasm. The focus has shifted from traditional work transfer to upfront transformation and automation! And that is super exciting!

Deloitte 2016 Global Outsourcing Survey

Therefore, businesses are challenging traditional methods of building software and driving a huge competitive advantage!

But what is the best outsourcing option for your business? Let’s dissect each one of them!

Location: what distinguishes offshore from nearshore

Typically, software development outsourcing can be described as nearshore or offshore. But what’s the real difference? In practice, it’s the distance between the contractor and the provider:

Nearshore Software Developement: outsourcing in countries in the same or similar time zone, located in bordering countries or a short distance away;

Offshore Software Developement: outsourcing: to regions that are overseas or more than four time zones away.

For example, if you are in the United Kingdom, it would be considered “nearshore outsourcing” any provider located in South, Central and Eastern Europe, such as Portugal, Spain, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Romania, and Poland. Although all these countries are relatively close to you, only Portugal is in the same time zone (which has a major impact on a daily basis).

India, on the other hand, is considered an offshore outsourcing destination. With a time difference of almost 6 hours, it is located at more than 4,000 miles away and a flight distance of more than 8 hours.

Why proximity matters in software development outsourcing

Destinations like India, China and Vietnam were the standard outsourcing countries for more than a decade. However, in the last years, businesses have started to see the benefits of building outsourcing partnerships with nearby countries.

Although these low-cost countries have extremely low wages, there is a big misconception that offshore outsourcing is cheap. If you look deeper, you’ll find a pool of hidden cost – management attention, communication, and co-ordination expenses. Not to mention taxes or duties that sometimes might be due. These ventures turn out to be quite expensive.

That’s why businesses are changing their game plan. Nowadays, geographical and cultural proximity play a crucial role in the outsourcing industry.

Same or similar time zone, shared language, and proximity mean you can fully be in control and involved in your project.

Of course, cost efficiency is one of the major factors as well. But the real price is factored in and seldom does the evaluation include solely the daily rate of the development team.

Modesty aside, a great example of

a premium value-to-cost ratio is Portugal

. In Portugal you’ll find a pool of talent, prime location, social and political stability, excellent accessibility and great technological infrastructures. Portugal is seriously considered one of the most competitive outsourcing destinations.

Can you Outsource and still be Agile? It’s all about communication

Definitely. And,

from our experience

, it can make or break an entire development project.

It is common to say that Agile is only suitable for small and co-located teams. However, stats are showing that’s not only the case. The

10th Annual State of Agile Report

shows that 71% of agile teams are geographically distributed in some manner. Moreover, according to

12th Annual State of Agile Report

, 45% of respondents are using agile practices to manage outsourced development projects and 40% of respondents indicated they plan to increase the use of agile in outsourced development projects in the next 24 months.

These numbers show that Agile

can and should

be used in software development outsourcing. The emphasis in mutual trust, communication, collaboration, and flexibility, results in a 98% of success of Agile Projects.

VersionOne 12th Annual State of Agile Report

We believe that, if you want to find success in your Outsourcing projects, communication is of paramount importance. And that’s why we are bringing out Agile in a post about Outsourcing. The adoption of Agile methodologies makes it easier to avoid misconceptions, misunderstandings and, in general, miscommunication.

If you want to succeed in Outsourcing, it’s easier if you adopt Agile methodologies. Make sure you’ll find a partner who shares the same vision.

Nearshore as a value-added solution

Software development Outsourcing is now the new normal. But the latest research shows a shift in industry thinking. Outsourcing is not just about saving money anymore. It’s seen as a critical tool in innovation and automation.

However, the biggest challenge for a successful project is managing the communication. Proximity – geographical and cultural -, language, common technologies and shared methodologies, all play an important part when it comes to choosing your outsourcing partner.

Whether you choose a nearshore or offshore outsourcing, the most significant thing is to choose a partner who understands you and with whom you can keep a relationship of trust and team work.

What about you? Are you looking to extend your development team?

Let us help!

Share your needs with us
